bioproject.title: Causes Lyme disease
bioproject.description: Borrelia burgdorferi strain B31. This is the type strain (ATCC 35210) for this organism and was derived by limited dilutional cloning from the original Lyme-disease tick isolate derived by A. Barbour.

bioproject.title: Causes periodontal disease, gum inflamation
bioproject.description: Treponema denticola ATCC 35405. Treponema denticola ATCC 35405 was isolated from a human periodontal pocket and is the type strain of this organism.

bioproject.organism: Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum str. Nichols
bioproject.title: Causative agent of syphilis
bioproject.description:
Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum. This organism is the causative agent of endemic and venereal syphilis. This sexual transmitted disease was first discovered in Europe at the end of the fifteenth century, however, the causative agent was not identified until 1905. At one time syphilis was the third most commonly reported communicable disease in the USA. Syphilis is characterized by multiple clinical stages and long periods of latent, asymptomatic infection. Although effective therapies have been available since the introduction of penicillin, syphilis remains a global health problem.

Treponema pallidum subsp. pallidum strain Nichols. This strain was originally isolated in 1912 from a neurosyphilitic patient and is virulent.

bioproject.organism: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94
bioproject.title: Causes infertility, infectious abortions, septicemia, meningitis
bioproject.description: Campylobacter fetus subsp. venerealis str. Azul-94. Field isolate obtained from an aborted Bos taurus (cow) fetus (Year: 1994, Place: Tandil, Argentina).

bioproject.organism: Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168 = ATCC 700819
bioproject.title: Leading cause of food poisoning (altered virulence strain)
bioproject.description: Campylobacter jejuni strain NCTC11168. This strain (originally 5636/77) was isolated from a diarrheic patient in 1977 and minimally passaged. This strain displays aberrant virulence phenotypes in animal models and tissue culture. Contains many homopolymeric tracts in the genome which result in hypervariable sequences in many genes having to do with cell surface structures. These sequences result in hypervarible antigenic diversity and immune evasion. Overall, the genome contains very few repetitive DNA sequences and very few coding regions arranged in operons. Pathogenicity factors include cytolethal-distending toxin, hemolysin-like toxins, and a type II secretion system.

bioproject.organism: Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4
bioproject.title: Aquatic bacterium that cause tularemia
bioproject.description: Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis strain Schu S4. This subspecies is virulent in humans, and the strain is a clinical isolate that is also virulent in an animal model. Originally isolated from a human case of tularemia in 1951. Genome analysis indicates the presence of a large number of pseudogenes, many that disrupt important metabolic pathways, which is the reason for the exacting nutritional requirements of this organism. There is a duplicated pathogenicity island that has also been detected in strain LVS and mutations in the iglA, iglC, or pdpD genes affect the ability of the pathogen to survive in macrophages. The genome also contains genes for type IV pili production and capsular polysaccharide genes similar to those of Bacillus anthracis as well as numerous ABC transporters. There are a large number of insertion sequences including a mariner element, which is a transposon typically found in eukaryotes and is the first instance of this element to be found in a microbe, which may have acquired it during transit through one of the insect vectors.

bioproject.title: Microorganism of putrefaction
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas fluorescens strain Pf0-1. This strain was isolated from agricultural loam (sand, clay, and organic matter) soil in 1988 by Compeau et al. and is well adapted to soil environments.

bioproject.title: Soil-born pathogen that naturally infects plant roots
bioproject.description:
Ralstonia solanacearum strain GMI1000. This strain is a race 1 strain isolated from the tomato plant and is also pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana. It specifically invades the plant xylem.

Pathogenicity factors include an extracellular polysaccharide that protects the bacterium and a type III secretion system (the hrp system) that is encoded on the megaplasmid and delivers effector molecules such as avirulence (Avr) proteins into the host cell. There is a type II secretion system for export of degradative enzymes such as plant cell wall hydrolases. This organism expresses a large number of outer membrane proteins including several that are related to hemagglutinins, as well as numerous fimbriae, including a type IV pilus for attachment and twitching motility. The two chromosomes contains many copies of insertion elements.

bioproject.title: Causes black rot and citrus canker
bioproject.description: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris strain 8004. This strain is a derivative of strain NCPBB No. 1145. The original was isolated from an inflected cauliflower in Sussex, United Kingdom, in 1958. Strain 8004 is a spontaneous rifampicin resistant strain and has been used extensively in many studies.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing bacterium
bioproject.description: Azotobacter vinelandii. This organism will provide information on the proteins involved in nitrogen fixation and the production of PHB and alginate.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing plant symbiont
bioproject.description:
Bradyrhizobium japonicum strain USDA110. This strain was isolated from Glycine hispida in 1959 in Florida, USA, and has been widely studied because of its superior symbiotic nitrogen fixation with soybeans as compared to other strains. This strain contains a 681 Kb symbiosis island that contains genes for nitrogen fixation and root nodule formation. The chromosome also contains genes resembling those of type III and IV secretion systems.

The original strain designation of USDA110 was 3I1b110, which was gradually changed to USDA110 in the early 1960's with the development of serology and the recognition that 17 different serogroups could be distinguished. USDA110 is the serotype strain for the "110" serogroup. The type strain of the species is Bradyrhizobium japonicum USDA 6 which was isolated from soybean in Japan. USDA acquired this culture from the University of Tokyo in 1929. This culture has a different serogroup affinity to USDA 110 and is in fact the serotype strain of the 6 serogroup.

bioproject.title: Symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria
bioproject.description: Mesorhizobium loti strain MAFF303099. This strain contains 2 plasmids as well as a symbiotic island that is 610 Kb on the chromosome that is significantly divergent as compared to the symbiotic island of Mesorhizobium loti strain ICMP3153 but does contain root nodule formation and nitrogen-fixation genes. The symbiosis island contains genes similar to those for type III and IV secretion systems. Both plasmids pMLa and pMLb contain genes similar to type IV secretion genes.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing bacterium
bioproject.description: Sinorhizobium meliloti strain 1021. Streptomycin resistant derivative of strain 2011. This strain carries 2 megaplasmids, pSymA and pSymB. Nitrogen fixation functions and nodulation genes are found on pSymA. The second plasmid encodes a number of transport systems, including many ABC-type transporters. This organism does not have a type III secretion system like the other Rhizobia but does have a type IV secretion system.

bioproject.title: Methanol-utilizing bacterium
bioproject.description: Methylobacterium extorquens strain AM1. This strain can grow on methylamine or methanol, but not methane. It is an extensively studied laboratory strain.

bioproject.title: Uses methane as sole carbon and energy source
bioproject.description: Methylococcus capsulatus str. Bath. This organism will provide information on the proteins involved in methane oxidation.

bioproject.organism: Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1
bioproject.title: Aquatic bacterium that causes Legionnaire's disease
bioproject.description: Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1. This strain is the isolate from the initial event of Legionellosis in Philadelphia and is the type strain for this species.

bioproject.title: Causes gonorrhea
bioproject.description: Neisseria gonorrhoeae strain FA 1090. A serum-resistant streptomycin-resistant proline-requiring strain isolated from a patient with disseminated gonococcal infections.

bioproject.title: Causes respiratory diseases
bioproject.description: Bordetella bronchiseptica strain RB50. This strain was isolated from a rabbit. The genome contains a type IV pilus biosynthetic operon that produces pili for attachment. The chromosome also contains the gene for pertussis toxin but it is not expressed.

bioproject.title: Causes bronchitis and other respiratory deseases
bioproject.description: Bordetella parapertussis strain 12822 . This strain was isolated from an infected infant in Germany in 1993. The genome contains the gene for pertussis toxin but does not express it.

bioproject.title: Causes bronchitis and other respiratory deseases
bioproject.description: Bordetella pertussis Tohama I. This strain was originally isolated from a patient with whooping cough and has been studied extensively for over 40 years. The chromosome contains a type IV secretion system for export of the pertussis toxin, a typical AB type toxin. The B subunits are involved in attachment to host cells, and the A subunit, the ADP-ribosylating factor, interferes with cell signalling pathways by increasing intracellular cAMP concentrations. The result is an inability of phagocytes to kill foreign invaders such as the bacterium.

bioproject.title: Causes bordetellosis
bioproject.description: Bordetella avium strain 197N. This strain is a spontaneous nalidixic acid-resistant derivative of virulent strain 197.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes soft rot disease in plants
bioproject.description:
Dickeya dadantii strain 3937. Formerly Erwinia chrysanthemi, this strain (3937) is wild-type and was isolated from Saintpaulia plants. It is a well characterized strain and has been used extensively. It produces important exoenzymes, including 5 types of pectinases, pectin methylesterases and an acetylesterase for degradation of modified plant cell wall components.

Recent taxonomic revisions have altered the name of this organism over the course of the genome project; This organism is now named Dickeya dadantii, but was previously named Erwinia chrysanthemi and Pectobacterium chrysanthemi. Dickeya dadantii is an important model system for studying the molecular basis and regulation of soft-rot pathogenesis. Soft-rot associated enterobacteria cause devastating disease on a wide range of plant host species including agriculturally important crops and ornamentals. Most of the genome sequencing took place at The Institute for Genomic Reasearch (TIGR) with final gap closure and finishing at the University of Wisconsin. An international network of collaborators worked with GEL personnel to annotate and analyze this genome sequence.
bioproject.organization: The Genome Evolution Laboratory at the University of Wisconsin

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes multiple hospital-acquired infections
bioproject.description: Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae strain MGH 78578. This strain was isolated from a patient in 1994.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Enteritidis str. LK5
bioproject.title: Major cause of food poisoning in US
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Enteritidis strain LK5. This serovar, also known as Salmonella enteritidis, is often associated with salmonellosis and is the major cause of food poisoning in the United States (gastroenteritis) due to the advent of mass chicken egg production. It is the only human pathogen in the Salmonella group that routinely contaminates chicken eggs, although it does not cause discernible disease in the chicken. This strain was isolated from a chicken.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Pullorum
bioproject.title: Fowl-adapted Salmonella
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Pullorum. This serovar is fowl-adapted and causes dysentery.

bioproject.title: Extremely virulent organism that causes plague
bioproject.description: Yersinia pestis strain CO92. This strain is a recent Orientalis subtype isolated in the USA from a patient who died of pneumonic plague after acquiring the disease from an infected cat. This strain is 50 Kbp larger than the Yersinia pestis KIM10+ genome due to numerous insertions.

bioproject.organism: Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961
bioproject.title: Aquatic organism that causes Cholera
bioproject.description: Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar ElTor str. N16961. This is an epidemic serogroup of Vibrio cholerae isolated in 1971 in Bangladesh and is distinguished from the classical biotype due to hemolysin production. It contains 2 chromosomes. The first, and larger chromosome, contains many essential cell functions, as well as virulence genes contained within pathogenicity islands (PAIs). One major pathogenicity determinant is encoded within a PAI that is contained inside an integrated phage (CTXphi) on chromosome 1 that codes for the cholera toxin, an adenylate cyclase. Once the toxin is injected into host cells, it results in secretion of chlorine ions, which leads to increased water secretion, dehydration, and eventually, death. Up to 20 litres of water a day may be lost. The second chromosome also has important cell functions, but has a preponderance of genes associated with energy and transport functions, including signal transduction systems, and in addition, DNA repair enzymes. Chromosome 2 also has the integron island, a large variable region of the chromosome that functions as a gene capture system, some of which are associated with antibiotic resistance. There are 105 genes that have copies on both chromosomes.

bioproject.title: Obligate pathogen that causes sexually-transmitted chancroid and enhances HIV transmission
bioproject.description: Haemophilus ducreyi 35000HP . This strain is a human passage derivative of Haemophilus ducreyi strain 35000 that is serum-resistant.

bioproject.organism: Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70
bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes a range of infections in humans and animals
bioproject.description: Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70. Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida str. Pm70 was isolated in 1995 from a case of fowl cholera in chickens. This strain is a serotype 3 capsular type A strain and will provide information on the production and regulation of proteins involved in virulence and disease.

bioproject.title: Causes bovine anaplasmosis
bioproject.description: Anaplasma marginale strain St. Maries. This strain was recovered from an acutely infected cow from Northern Idaho and bears an msp1a genotype of JBB. This strain is transmitted by ticks and is known to be virulent.

bioproject.title: Nine Mile phase I isolate that causes Q fever
bioproject.description: Coxiella burnetii strain RSA 493. This is a Nine Mile phase I isolate which contains a small plasmid QpH1.

bioproject.title: Obligate intracellular pathogen that causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
bioproject.description: Rickettsia conorii strain Malish 7. This strain was isolated from a human in South Africa.

bioproject.title: Causes louse-borne typhus and Mediterranean spotted fever (avirulent strain)
bioproject.description: Rickettsia prowazekii strain Madrid E. This strain is an egg-passaged attentuated avirulent strain that has been used as a live vaccine and was originally isolated from a typhus patient in Madrid.

bioproject.title: Causes bacillary angiomatosis
bioproject.description: Bartonella quintana str. Toulouse. Bartonella quintana str. Toulouse was isolated from human blood in Toulouse, France in 1993. There is evidence of extensive genome reduction in comparison to other Bartonella species which may be associated with the limited host range of Bartonella quintana.

bioproject.title: Serovar D strain that causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydia trachomatis strain D/UW-3/CX. This is a trachoma biovar, serovar D strain.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen of mammalian intestinal tract
bioproject.description: Bacteroides fragilis strain ATCC 25285. This organism can become an opportunistic pathogen, infecting anywhere in the body and causing abcess formation. Enterotoxigenic Bacterioides fragilis (ETBF) is associated with diarrheal diseases. This strain is the type strain.

bioproject.title: Rumen cellulolytic bacteria
bioproject.description: Fibrobacter succinogenes subsp. succinogenes strain S85. The production of cellulolytic enzymes by Fibrobacter succinogenes subsp. succinogenes strain S85 has been extensively studied. Strain S85 is the type strain for this organism and the genome sequence will provide information on the production and regulation of these enzymes.

bioproject.title: Bacterium associated with periodontal disease
bioproject.description: Porphyromonas gingivalis strain W83. This strain (also known as HG66) is virulent in a mouse model and has been extensively studied. It was originally isolated by H. Werner in the 1950s in Bonn, Germany, from an unknown human infection.

bioproject.title: Aerotolerant organism that causes ovine footrot
bioproject.description: Dichelobacter nodosus strain VCS1703A. This strain is a virulent type G strain which is naturally transformable and has been used in virulence studies.

bioproject.title: Bacterium capable of metal corrosion
bioproject.description: Desulfovibrio vulgaris subsp. vulgaris strain Hildenborough. This strain was isolated from clay soil near Hildenborough, UK in 1946. A plasmid containing genes that encode nif functions (nitrogen fixation) as well as a type III secretion system (TTSS) is found in this organism The function of the TTSS genes is unknown.

bioproject.title: Nitrifying bacterium
bioproject.description: Nitrosomonas europaea ATCC 19718. The chromosome of Nitrosomonas europaea ATCC 19718 contains numerous gene and DNA duplications, including those for the oxidation of ammonia, which may be due to the numerous insertion sequences also present.

bioproject.title: Acidophile used for bioremediation and recovery of important metals
bioproject.description: Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans ATCC 23270. This organism was isolated from bituminous coal mine effluent. The genome sequence of this organism will provide information on the production and regulation of proteins involved in iron-oxidation and will be used for comparative analysis with other iron-oxidizing bacteria.

bioproject.title: Abundant soil organism that degrades cellulose
bioproject.description: Cytophaga hutchinsonii ATCC 33406. The genome sequence of this strain will provide information on the production and regulation of proteins involved in the degradation of chitin, cellulose and other compounds.

bioproject.title: A bacterium with alternative energy-converting pathways.
bioproject.description: Rhodobacter capsulatus strain SB1003. This strain is a derivative strain isolated in the laboratory of Barry Marrs from the classical progenitor strain B10. It is rifampicin-resistant, produces GTA, and is capable of growing under high illumination (resistant to photooxidative killing).

bioproject.title: Metabolically diverse phototrophic bacterium
bioproject.description: Rhodobacter sphaeroides strain 2.4.1. This is the type strain for this organism.

bioproject.title: Metabolically diverse organism important in carbon cycle and bioremediation
bioproject.description: Rhodopseudomonas palustris strain CGA009. This organism contains genes for bacteriochlorophyll and carotenoid synthesis as well as genes for the light reaction center that allow photophosphorylation in addition to carbon (RubisCO) and nitrogen fixation (nitrogenase) genes. It also has genes for the oxidation of inorganic compounds such as thiosulfate and hydrogen and nitrogenases for nitrogen fixation. This bacterium can degrade aromatic compounds and the genome encodes a large repertoire of degradative enzymes. There are a type II, type III, and two type IV secretion systems on the chromosome, and the organism also contains a small cryptic plasmid.

bioproject.title: Bacterium that can grow using anoxygenic photosynthesis
bioproject.description: Rhodospirillum rubrum ATCC 11170. This bacterium can grow using carbon monoxide as the sole carbon and energy source and the cells contain a well characterized nitrogenase system that is post-translationally modified by ADP-ribosylation.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic phototroph
bioproject.description: Chloroflexus aurantiacus J-10-fl. Chloroflexus aurantiacus J-10-fl (DSM 635) was isolated from the Hakone hot spring area in Japan and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Model cyanobacterium for analysis of photosynthetic organisms
bioproject.description: Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803. This cyanobacterium was isolated from a freshwater lake in 1968 and is easily transformed by exogenous DNA. The photosynthetic apparatus is very similar to the one found in plants. This organism also exhibits phototactic movement.

bioproject.title: Cellulolytic bacterium that inhabits rumen
bioproject.description: Ruminococcus albus strain 8. Ruminococcus albus strain 8 was isolated from an alfalfa hay-fed cow. Cellulose degradation has been extensively studied in this organism and the genome sequence will provide information on the production and regulation of proteins involved in this process.

bioproject.title: Associated with mastitis in cattle
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus strain RF122. This strain is a common strain associated with mastitis in cattle. This organism is responsible for several hundred million dollars worth of annual economic loss to animal production each year

bioproject.title: Pathogenic clinical isolate that causes toxic-shock syndrome and staphylococcal scarlet fever
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus epidermidis strain RP62A. This strain is a strongly adherent, slime-producing, pathogenic strain isolated from a patient with intravascular catheter-associated sepsis.

bioproject.title: Extremely radiation-resistant soil bacterium
bioproject.description: Deinococcus radiodurans strain R1. This strain was reported as the R1 type strain, ATCC 13939. However, it was later stated that this strain is really the USUHS strain at the Uniformed Services University in Bethesda, Maryland, and has acquired nucleotide substitutions as compared to the R1 strain. It is known as ATCC BAA-816.

bioproject.organism: Streptococcus gordonii str. Challis substr. CH1
bioproject.title: Causes caries and periodontal diseases
bioproject.description: Streptococcus gordonii strain Challis. This strain is used extensively in the laboratory because of its well characterized transformation system.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that transfers vancomycin resistance to other bacteria
bioproject.description: Enterococcus faecalis strain V583. This strain is one of the first vancomycin-resistant strains isolated. This isolate came from a blood culture derived from a chronically-infected patient in 1987 from Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, Missouri. This strain was found to lack the cytolysin gene and a surface adhesin, Esp, that contributes to urinary tract infections. Mobile genetic elements make up one quarter of the genome.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that transfers vancomycin resistance to other bacteria
bioproject.description: Enterococcus faecium DO. Enterococcus faecium DO is an opportunistic pathogen that transfers vancomycin resistance to other bacteria.

bioproject.title: Used extensively in soft cheese production
bioproject.description:
Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis. This subspecies is used to make soft cheeses.

Lactococcus lactissubsp. lactis Il1403. This strain is used widely in laboratory research and is a plasmid-free derivative of strain IL594 isolated from a cheese starter culture. The genome shows many insertion sequences and prophages, and surprisingly, a large number of genes involved in respiration, suggesting that this organism may aerobically respire.

bioproject.title: Soil organism that causes opportunistic infections such as food poisoning
bioproject.description: Bacillus cereus strain ATCC 10987. This strain was isolated in Canada during a study of cheese spoilage. It contains a plasmid, pBc10987, that is similar to Bacillus anthracis toxin plasmid pXO1, but lacks the anthrax toxin genes.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic organism that produces thermostable spores and stable enzymes that are used in industry
bioproject.description: Geobacillus stearothermophilus strain 10. This strain was isolated from a hot spring in Yellowstone National Park and has been used in comparative analyses of thermophilic (high temperature) and mesophilic (medium temperature) Bacillus spp..

bioproject.title: Model organism for prokaryotic cell differentiation and development
bioproject.description: Bacillus subtilis subsp. subtilis str. 168. This strain was derived in 1947 from an X-ray irradiated strain, Marburg.

bioproject.title: Industrial producer of starch-based acetone, butanol, and ethanol.
bioproject.description: Clostridium acetobutylicum strain ATCC 824. This strain was isolated in 1924 from garden soil in Connecticut, USA, by E. Wyer and L. Rettger. It is one of the best studied solventogenic clostridia. The strain has been shown to be closely related to the historical Weizmann strain. It can utilize a broad range of mono- and disaccharides, starches, other substrates such as pectin, xylan, inulin and others. Solventogenic metabolic pathways of this strain have been elucidated. Most of the genes involved in solventogenesis are located on the megaplasmid pSOL1. The strain has been extensively studied from the physiological and bioengineering points of view, genetic systems have been developed that allow genes to be manipulated and solvent-tolerant and solvent-overproducing strains has been engineered.

bioproject.title: Etiological agent of antibiotic-associated diarrhea and pseudomembraneous colitis.
bioproject.description: Clostridium difficile strain 630. This strain is the epidemic type X variant that has been extensively studied in research and clinical laboratories. It produces both toxin A, and B.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of gas gangrene.
bioproject.description:
Clostridium. This genus comprises about 150 metabolically diverse species of anaerobes that are ubiquitous in virtually all anoxic habitats where organic compounds are present, including soils, aquatic sediments and the intestinal tracts of animals and humans. Characteristic of clostridia is the shape of their cells that resembles a drumstick or spindle ('kloster' is Greek for 'spindle'). This shape is attributed to the presence of endospores that develop under conditions unfavorable for vegetative growth and distend single cells terminally or sub-terminally. The endospores of many species are extremely sturdy and survive extended boiling in water and exposure to air. Spores germinate under conditions favorable for vegetative growth, such as anaerobiosis and presence of organic substrates. From the evolutionary perspective, clostridia are considered to be the most ancient bacteria. It is believed that present day Mollicutes (Eubacteria) have evolved regressively (i.e., by genome reduction) from gram-positive clostridia-like ancestors with a low GC content in DNA. Several species of clostridia (e.g., C. perfringens, C. botulinum, C. tetani) are known opportunistic toxin-producing pathogens in animals and humans. Some species are capable of producing organic solvents (acetone, ethanol, etc,), molecular hydrogen and other useful compounds. There are also species that can fix molecular nitrogen and thus are important participants in biological turnaround of nitrogen compounds in nature.

Clostridium perfringens. This organism is a causative agent of a wide spectrum of necrotic enterotoxicoses. In humans it is responsible for such diseases as gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis), food poisoning, necrotizing enterocolitis of infants and enteritis necroticans (pigbel). It also causes such animal diseases as lamb dysentery, ovine enterotoxemia (struck), pulpy kidney disease in lambs and other enterotoxemias in lambs and calves.

The bacterium is one of the most widely distributed pathogens in nature. It is commonly found in the environment (soil, sewage) and in the animal and human gastrointestinal tract as a member of the normal microflora. It is a fast growing (generation time 8-10 min) anaerobic flesh-eater. Active fermentative growth is accompanied by profuse generation of molecular hydrogen and carbon dioxide. Unlike most other clostridia, C. perfringens is non-motile. It is also oxygen tolerant which makes it an easy object to work with in laboratories. Systems for genetic manipulation of C. perfringens have been developed and the species became a model organism in clostridial genetic studies.

Known isolates belong to five distinct types (A, B, C, D, and E) that are distinguished based on the specific extracellular toxins they produce. Each of the toxins is responsible for a specific disease syndrome. Type A strains that cause gas gangrene produce toxin alpha (phospholypase C), theta (hemolysin), kappa (collagenase), mu (hyaluronidase), nu (DNAse) and neuraminidase which are all the enzymatic factors aiding the bacterium in invading and destruction of the host tissues.

Clostridium perfringens str. 13. This strain is a type A isolate from the soil. It can establish gas gangrene in a murine experimental model.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing bacterium and potential bioremediator.
bioproject.description: Clostridium pasteurianum sp. BC1. Clostridium pasteurianum sp. BC1 was isolated from coal-cleaning residues. It is a potential candidate for ameliorating radionuclide contamination at DOE sites as it has biochemical pathways that can convert water soluble uranyl (VI) ion, to a less soluble form of this element, U(IV).

bioproject.title: Causative agent of tetanus.
bioproject.description: Clostridium tetani strain E88. This strain is a virulent nonsporulating variant of strain Massachusetts used in vaccine production.

bioproject.title: Commercially available strain used for formula, yogurt, and fluid milk production
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus acidophilus strain NCFM. This organism is a normal inhabitant of the human intestinal tract. This strain was isolated from a human in 1970 and characterized at North Caroline State University. It is commercially available from Rhodia Inc., and is used for formula, yogurt, and fluid milk production.

bioproject.title: Major homofermentative Lactobacillus in human intestinal tract
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus gasseri ATCC 33323. Lactobacillus gasseri ATCC 33323 is a human isolate and is the type strain. This organism has been shown to have probiotic activities such as production of bacteriocins, macrophage stimulation and adherence to intestinal tissues.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes important food-born disease
bioproject.description: Listeria monocytogenes strain 4b F2365. This strain was isolated in 1985 in California, USA, during an outbreak of listeriosis among patients with AIDS. The strain is of serotype 4b and was isolated from a cheese product that caused the outbreak.

bioproject.title: Nonpathogenic as compared to Listeria monocytogenes
bioproject.description: Listeria innocua strain Clip11262. This strain is serovar 6a and is used for heterologous expression of Listeria monocytogenes genes. This bacterium lacks the virulence gene regulator, PrfA, that is present in Listeria monocytogenes and is responsible for regulation of many virulence genes in the genome.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of diphtheria.
bioproject.description: Corynebacterium diphtheriae biotype gravis strain NCTC13129. This strain was isolated in 1997 from the pharyngeal membrane of a 72-year-old unimmunized UK female with clinical diphtheria acquired during a short Baltic cruise. Knowing the genetic sequence of this modern strain is important for understanding how to successfully treat the disease that has recently started breaking out in the Eastern Europe.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of mycobacterial disease in children, the aged, and in immunocompromised individuals.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium avium strain 104. This strain is a common representative of the species complex. It was derived from an AIDS patient and has been characterized for virulence in the murine model of low-dose aerosol infection in that it could colonize the lung, proliferate within the tissue and disseminate to other organs. This strain will be used for comparative analysis with other Mycobacterium species.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of bovine tuberculosis.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium bovis subsp. bovis strain AF2122/97. This strain is a fully virulent strain that was isolated in 1997 in the UK from a cow suffering necrotic lesions in lung and bronchomediastinal lymph nodes. The strain was also reported to infect and persist in badgers that are considered to be a significant source of bovine infection.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of human leprosy.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium leprae strain TN. This strain (TN) was passaged through an armadillo in Tamil Nadu, India, and is the only strain of this species that has been successfully produced in quantities large enough for sequencing and biochemical analyses as the nine-banded armadillo was used as a surrogate host.

bioproject.organism: Mycobacterium avium subsp. paratuberculosis K-10 strain:k10
bioproject.title: Causative agent of  Johne's disease, or paratuberculosis, a chronic severe intestinal infection.
bioproject.description:
Mycobacterium avium subsp. paratuberculosis. This organism is a slowly growing species, with doubling times of around 22-24 hours. One of the important diagnostic features of this bacterium is that its growth in laboratory settings depends on the presence of mycobactin J, a natural siderophore. This bacterium is not common in the environment, and is predominantly found as an intracellular parasite. It causes a chronic granulomatous enteritis termed Johne's disease or paratuberculosis. The desease affects domestic and free-ranging ruminants, but has also been reported in primates, rabbits, stoats and foxes. The usually fatal disease is characterized by weight loss and diarrhea, after a long pre-clinical phase. Treatment is ineffective and economically impracticable. Paratuberculosis in domestic livestock entails significant economic losses in the dairy industry totaling $1.5 billion annually. Several reports suggest a role for this organism in the etiology of Crohn's disease, a severe inflammatory bowel disease in humans.

Mycobacterium avium subsp. paratuberculosis strain K-10. This strain was isolated from a dairy herd in Wisconsin in the 1970's by investigators from the USDA National Animal Disease Center. It is an extensively studied low passage clinical strain and is amenable to genetic manipulation.

bioproject.title: Generally non-pathogenic mycobacterium capable of causing soft tissue lesions.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium smegmatis strain MC2 155. This strain (MC2 155) is a mutant of M. smegmatis. It was isolated in 1990. Unlike other strains of this species, MC2 can be 10 to 100 thousand times more efficiently transformed with plasmid vectors using electroporation than the parental strain and thus is invaluable in analysis of mycobacterial gene function, expression and replication.

bioproject.title: The wild-type strain for the species, used for comparative genomics.
bioproject.description: Streptomyces ambofaciens strain ATCC 23877. This is the wild-type and the best studied strain of the species. In addition to netropsin and spiramycin, this strain has been shown, based on genomic data reconfirmed experimentally, to produce a novel angucycline-like polyketide antibiotic.
bioproject.organization: Dynamique des Genomes et Adaptation Microbienne, UMR 1128 INRA - Universite de Lorraine, France

bioproject.title: Thermophilic organism found in decaying organic matter.
bioproject.description: Thermobifida fusca strain YX. This strain is one of the original isolates of T. fusca.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of Whipple's disease.
bioproject.description: Tropheryma whipplei str. Twist. This is the type strain for the species, and is used for comparative genome analysis.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of polyarthritis and septicemia in goats, sheep and cows
Causative agent of a wide range of urogenital and respiratory tract infections
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma genitalium strain G-37. This strain was isolated as a urethral specimen from a male patient with nongonococcal urethritis. This is the type strain for the species and is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Etiologic agent of tracheobronchitis and atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma pneumoniae strain M129 ATCC29342. This strain is a clinical isolate from a patient with atypical pneumonia.

bioproject.title: Etiologic agent of murine respiratory and genital mycoplasmosis.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma pulmonis strain UAB CTIP. This is a popular and well-studied laboratory strain. The respiratory disease it causes is one of the the most important pathologies in laboratory rats and mice, and thus a good model for studying mycoplasmal infections.

bioproject.title: Causes a wide range of infections of the urogenital or respiratory tracts
bioproject.description: Ureaplasma parvum serovar 3 str. ATCC 700970. Ureaplasma parvum serovar 3 is the serovar most commonly isolated from humans and this strain was obtained by E. Freundt at the Institue of Medical Microbiology, University of Aarhus, Aarhus, Denmark.

bioproject.title: Methane-producing thermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Methanocaldococcus jannaschii DSM 2661. Methanocaldococcus jannaschii DSM 2661 was isolated from a hydrothermal vent in the east Pacific Rise and is the type strain for the species.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic methane-producing archeon
bioproject.description: Methanosarcina barkeri strain fusaro. Methanosarcina barkeri strain Fusaro was isolated from mud samples taken from the freshwater lake, Lago del Fusaro near Naples, Italy.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic sulfate-reducing archaeon
bioproject.description: Archaeoglobus fulgidus strain VC-16. This is the type strain (DSM 4304) of the Archaeoglobales, and was isolated from a geothermally heated sea floor at Vulcano Island, Italy. Doubling time is four hours under optimal conditions. The organism is an autotrophic or organotrophic sulfate/sulfite respirer. An additional distinguishing characteristic is blue-green fluorescence at 420 nm.

bioproject.title: Chemoheterotrophic obligate extreme halophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Haloarcula marismortui ATCC 43049. This organism was isolated from the Dead Sea and will provide information on the proteins necessary for adaptation to a high salt environment.

bioproject.title: Chemoheterotrophic obligate extreme halophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Halobacterium salinarium strain R1. Halobacterium salinarium strain R1(DSM 671) forms translucent red colonies as opposed to the opaque pink colonies formed by Halobacterium salinarium NRL. Strain R1 has no gas vacuoles and will be used for comparison with other Halobacterium species.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic acidophilic sulfur-metabolizing archeon
bioproject.description: Sulfolobus solfataricus strain P2. This strain is a model organism for studying crenarchaeal biology and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic acidophilic archaea
bioproject.description: Thermoplasma acidophilum strain DSM 1728. This strain is the type strain for this species, and was isolated from a burning refuse coal pile from the Friar Tuck mine in Indiana, USA.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic organism that shows extensive horizontal gene transfer from archaea
bioproject.description: Thermotoga maritima strain MSB8. This hyperthermophilic organism was originally isolated from a geothermal marine area near Vulcano, Italy. Strain MSB8 is the type strain. It is representative of a very deep branch of eubacteria and a very large portion of the genome, 24% of all ORFs, is similar to archaeal genes, suggesting horizontal gene transfer, a hypothesis supported by the fact that many regions of the chromosome containing these genes have a significantly different composition as compared to the rest of the genome. This organism appears to live in a rich environment as it encodes a large number of transporters, both for import and export, of complex substrates such as carbohydrates, including a type II secretion system that may be used to export extracellular enzymes for degradation of biopolymers.

bioproject.title: Porphyra yezoensis EST project
bioproject.description: To understand the genetic system in red algae, large scale EST analysis of Porphyra yezoensis has been going on at the Kazusa DNA Research Institute. Large number of sequences have currently been generated from both gametophytic and sporophytic tissues of P. yezoensis Ueda (strain TU-1). The sequence data is available from the Kazusa website.

bioproject.title: Emiliania huxleyi EST sequencing projects
bioproject.description:
Large scale EST sequencing of Emiliania huxleyi is being carried out at California State University, San Marcos.
In addition, an EST project is also in progress at the University of Iowa with an aim to understand the process of eukaryotic endosymbiosis.

bioproject.title: Alexandrium tamarense EST project
bioproject.description: To understand the process of endosymbiosis, there is a Joint NSF-USDA funded project to sequence large scale ESTs from Alexandrium tamarense and Emiliania huxleyi which is the source of plastid for A. tamarense. Sequencing is being carried out at the University of Iowa.

bioproject.title: Refseq project
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence assembly for Arabidopsis is created by NCBI based on the genome data provided by The Arbidopsis Information Resource (TAIR). Functional annotation is continuously being updated, last updated in February, 2014.

Mitochondrial genome of Arabidopsis was sequenced at the Institut fur Genbiologische Forschung, Berlin, Germany and the chloroplast genome was sequenced at the Kazusa DNA Research Institute, Japan

bioproject.title: Glycine max Map
bioproject.description: Three maps are presented. Two are composite maps constructed by integrating the mapping data from many mapping endeavors that use three mapping populations: the USDA/Iowa State University population, the University of Utah RIL population and the University of Nebraska NIL population. The third map is the result of a concerted effort to develop SSR probes and map them in the mapping populations underlying the composite maps plus two other populations.

bioproject.title: chloroplast genome completely sequenced
bioproject.description: Medicago truncatula chloroplast genome was sequenced at the University of Oklahoma in partnership with the noble foundation. The DNA sequence consists of one contiguous 124,039 base pair circle. Artificially linearizing the genome shows Medicago chloroplast genomic sequence to be co-linear with the arabadopsis, tobacco and most other chloroplast genomes. Semi-automated annotation of the chloroplast genome using Web-Artemis is available.

bioproject.title: Sequencing of the tomato genome by the international consortium
bioproject.description: Sequencing of the tomato genome will be done by an international consortium of researchers as part of the Solanaceae Genomics Project. The plan is to sequence the gene rich regions of all 12 chromosomes on BAC by BAC basis and annotate it. The US has agreed to sequence chromosomes 1 and 10 with the majority of the funding by the NSF and the USDA Plant Genome program. Other participating member countries are Korea (chromosome 2), China (chromosome 3 and 11), UK (chromosome 4), India (chromosome 5), The Netherlands (chromosome 6), France (chromosome 7), Japan (chromosome 8) Spain (chromosome 9) and Italy (chromosome 12).

bioproject.title: Oat mapping projects
bioproject.description: Despite difficulties associated with mapping a large hexaploid genome with numerous chromosomal rearrangements, various diploid and hexaploid maps have been generated for oats. All the data is maintained by GrainGenes database which is supported by the USDA-ARS Plant Genome Research Program.

bioproject.title: Barley genetic maps
bioproject.description: Barley mapping data is being maintained by GrainGenes. Currently twenty-five maps are available at NCBI.

bioproject.title: Whole genome RefSeq project for Oryza sativa japonica group
bioproject.description: The rice chromosome GenBank accessions submitted by the Rice Annotation Program are processed within NCBI to generate the RefSeq accessions. The processing includes assignment of RefSeq accessions to the annotated mRNA and CDS, and assignment of Entrez Gene ids to annotated genes. This processing also enables tracking of annotation elements through future updates. The vocabulary of gene names is explicitly described in Rice, 1:72-84 (2008).

bioproject.title: Zea mays RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: Complete sequence of the maize chloroplast genome has been reported by Maier et al.

bioproject.title: Mitochondrial genome squencing
bioproject.description:
The University of Cincinnati, the University of Georgia, and the University of Kentucky sequenced the genome of Pneumocystis carinii using shotgun sequencing.

In addition, the Sanger Institute carried out a complementary effort to sequence the telomeres of Pneumocystis carinii chromosomes.

bioproject.title: Schizosaccharomyces pombe 972h- RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The Schizosaccharomyces pombe reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Schizosaccharomyces pombe strain 972h- genome sequence, assembly, and annotation submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by PomBase. The RefSeq genome can be viewed in NCBI's Map Viewer browser.

bioproject.title: Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288c RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description:
The Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain S288c reference sequence (RefSeq) genome and annotation originate from the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Third Party Annotation (TPA) submission which in turn was provided to NCBI by the Saccharomyces Genome Database (SGD).

For additional information, please see the RefSeq Project chapter in the NCBI Handbook.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing, assembly, and annotation
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute and Monsanto collaborated to sequence the Aspergillus nidulans strain FGSC-4A genome at 13X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The assembly was created from 10X reads sequenced at the Broad Institute combined with 3X reads provided by Monsanto. The current assembly represents approximately 96% of the Aspergillus nidulans genome; it excludes ribosomal RNA genes and very highly conserved repetitive sequence. The genome has been annotated using automated gene prediction tools, and the assembly has been anchored to a linkage map.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing of strain Af293
bioproject.description: J. Craig Venter Institute and the Sanger Institute sequenced the Aspergillus fumigatus strain Af293 genome at 10.5X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The draft genome was finished, resulting in a final assembly that contains 19 contigs in eight supercontigs.

bioproject.title: Neurospora crassa OR74A RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly (see linked project PRJNA13841). Annotation on the RefSeq genomic records is propagated from the INSDC submission. RefSeq records may differ from the submitted annotation in format details, some protein names, and occasionally in feature location details.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing
bioproject.description: The DOE Joint Genome Institute sequenced the Phanerochaete chrysosporium strain RP-78 genome at approximately 10.6X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. They end-sequenced 2000 cosmid clones to corroborate the assembled genome. The resulting assembly contains 29.6 Mb of non-repetitive sequence in 349 scaffolds greater than 3 kb.

bioproject.title: EST sequencing
bioproject.description: The University of Oklahoma, in collaboration with Texas A&M University, end-sequenced over 5,000 cDNA clones derived from the Fusarium sporotrichioides genome. Excluding ribosomal and mitochondrial sequences, they generated approximately 7,500 high-quality EST sequences larger than 100 bp.

bioproject.title: Entamoeba histolytica genome sequencing project
bioproject.description:
Entamoeba histolytica (strain HM-1:IMSS), was the first human amoeba to have its genome sequenced, assembled and analyzed. Whole genome shotgun sequencing with small insert libraries was used to carry out sequencing to a 12.5-fold coverage. The sequencing project was a collaborative effort between JCVI (TIGR) and The Sanger Institute.

The exact number of chromosomes in E. histolytica is uncertain due to difficulties in condensing and resolving them by pulse-field gel electrophoresis. Approximately 9,938 predicted genes with an average size of 1.17 kb, comprise 49% of the genome. One third of this organism's predicted proteins (31.8%) do not have identifiable sequence homologues in other species.

The whole genome shotgun sequence data from E. histolytica strain HM-1:IMSS has been deposited in GenBank. The current version of the project (02) has the accession number AAFB02000000, consists of 1529 scaffolds DS571145-DS572673 and represents 8x coverage of the genome.

This sequencing project was completed by a collaboration between JCVI (TIGR) and the Sanger Institute.

bioproject.title: An EST project has begun for this protist
bioproject.description: This group has started to sequence ESTs for Eimeria tenella, a parasitic protozoa.

bioproject.title: Cryptosporidium parvum Iowa II genome sequencing project
bioproject.description:
The sequencing of the genome of the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium parvum is a joint effort between the Advanced Genetics Analysis Center, University of Minnesota and the Medical Research Council, Laboratory of Molecular Biology,(UK).

The University of Minnesota has conducted a random shotgun approach to obtain the complete DNA sequence of the Iowa isolate of C. parvum. Source material was purified from parasite oocysts from the feces of infected calves, using a continuous sucrose gradient. Purified DNA was randomly sheared to construct a 2-5 kb genomic library, which was sequenced to 13X coverage. In addition to this effort, end-sequencing of large-insert genomic clones will provide a scaffold to verify DNA assembly.

The C.parvum nuclear genome is approximately 10.4 Mb, organized in eight chromosomes with sizes varying from 1.04 to 1.5 Mb. Surprisingly, unlike most Apicomplexa, C. parvum appears to lack a plastid genome.

The MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology has completed a physical map of the Iowa isolate of C.parvum , and sequencing and analysis of Chromosome 6. Sequence analysis of this chromosome revealed little synteny and protein similarity with Plasmodium, another Apicomplexan parasite.

All sequence data from C. parvum has been submitted to GenBank CM000429:CM000436.

Analysis of the C. parvum genome will provide information regarding genome structure and organization, host-parasite interaction and pathogenesis, and the development of drug and vaccine targets.

bioproject.title: Causal agent of Toxoplasmosis
bioproject.description:
The Sanger Center is shotgun sequencing chromosome 1 from Toxoplasma gondii and end sequencing a whole genome BAC library. The BAC end sequencing has been completed, and the shotgun sequence of chromosome 1 has been performed to 5x coverage.

The genome is 30 Mb in size and organized in 14 chromosomes.

bioproject.title: Plasmodium berghei whole genome shotgun sequencing project
bioproject.description:
The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute Pathogen Sequencing Unit has undertaken the sequencing of the Plasmodium berghei genome, which has an estimated size of 25-27 Mb and is comprised of 14 chromosomes. DNA for this partial shotgun sequencing project was obtained from asynchronous bloodstages of clone 15cy1 of the ANKA strain of P. berghei.

The Plasmodium berghei whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession CAAI00000000. The current version of the project (01) has the accession number CAAI01000000, and consists of sequences CAAI01000001-CAAI01007479. This initial version is a low coverage genome assembly containing automated annotation and should be analyzed and interpreted with these caveats. The sequence and assembly have been released in this preliminary state by the Sanger Institute for the benefit of the scientific community.

bioproject.title: Plasmodium chabaudi whole genome shotgun sequencing project
bioproject.description:
The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute Pathogen Sequencing Unit has undertaken the sequencing of the Plasmodium chabaudi genome, which has an estimated size of 30 Mb and is comprised of 14 chromosomes.

The P. chabaudi whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession CAAJ00000000. The current version of the project (01) has the accession number CAAJ01000000, and consists of sequences CAAJ01000001-CAAJ01010690. This initial version is a low coverage genome assembly containing automated annotation and should be analyzed and interpreted with these caveats. The sequence and assembly have been released in this preliminary state by the Sanger Institute for the benefit of the scientific community.

bioproject.title: Reference genome sequence for Plasmodium falciparum
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly for Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 is provided by NCBI and is based on sequence, assembly and annotation submitted by the P. falciparum Genome Sequencing Consortium. The reference genome sequence can be viewed in Map Viewer, where the sequence data is displayed in a genomic context with additional maps and data elements.

bioproject.title: Partial genome shotgun sequencing of Plasmodium knowlesi
bioproject.description: As a complementary effort to the Plasmodium falciparum genome sequence project, the 25 Mb genome of Plasmodium knowlesi has been sequenced using a partial genome shotgun approach at the Sanger Institute. Together with the genome sequences of the malaria parasites P. falciparum, P. yoelii, P. vivax, P. knowlesi and P. chabaudi, the P. knowlesi genomic sequence will provide a deeper insight into the evolutionary history of these species. The combined projects will provide interesting tools for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Plasmodium vivax isolate:Salvador I Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description: The Plasmodium vivax genome is comprised of 14 chromosomes with an estimated total size of 30 Mb. The Salvador I strain was selected for sequencing, a strain that was initially isolated from a human infection in El Salvador and has since been passaged through human and monkey subjects. The P. vivax genome was sequenced at The Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR) using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) strategy to a final sequencing depth of 10X. This sequence data has been deposited in GenBank under accession AAKM00000000, and a annotated and curated copy of this data is available in RefSeq.

bioproject.title: EST sequencing project for Babesia bovis
bioproject.description: The ESTs (Expressed Sequence Tags) are derived from a cDNA Library supplied by The Department of Infectious Diseases and Immunology of Utrecht University. The cDNA was prepared from mRNA extracted from an asynchronous in vitro culture of B. bovis strain C61411, in bovine erythrocytes. Approximately 13,000 ESTs were generated, representing about 2600 genes.

bioproject.title: The sequence of this protozoan parasite has been completed
bioproject.description: The Sanger Institute has sequenced the genome of Theileria annulata to an 8x coverage using a whole genome shotgun approach. This was completed as a collaborative project with the University of Glasgow, Scotland. An EST project is ongoing to generate 10,000 EST reads for T. annulata to help with gene identification.

bioproject.title: Encephalitozoon cuniculi GB-M1 RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly (see linked project PRJNA13833). Annotation on the RefSeq genomic records is propagated from the INSDC submission. RefSeq records may differ from the submitted annotation in format details, some protein names, and occasionally in feature location details.

bioproject.title: The genome of this nematode was sequenced to a high quality draft version
bioproject.description: The Washington University Genome Sequencing Center (WashU-GSC) began a sequencing pilot project of Caenorhabditis briggsae to determine whether the sequence would aid in the annotation of C. elegans genomic sequence. This project then progressed and a high-quality draft sequence was completed and published. The Wash.U-GSC reported their analysis in Stein et al., PLoS Biology 1(2):E45:, 2003.

bioproject.title: Reference genome sequence for Caenorhabditis elegans
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is currently provided by WormBase. The genome can be viewed in NCBI's MapViewer browser.

Several other large scale projects focus on this small yet complex animal, whose cells and lineage are known and on which genetic analysis is easy. Examples include the genome wide ORFeome and interactome projects, led by Vidal; the C.elegans gene knockout project; Kim microarray and several large scale RNAi experiments by Ahringer, Sugimoto, Hyman, Piano.

NCBI is working in close collaboration with the various data producing groups to provide integrated sequence and functional data for public display and use. The RefSeqs data sets are available for ftp in a variety of formats, including GenBank, FastA, ASN.1, and others from the NCBI anonymous FTP

For additional information, please see the RefSeq chapter in the NCBI Handbook.

bioproject.title: Expressed sequence tag (EST) project for Amblyomma americanum salivary gland cDNAs
bioproject.description:
The Advanced Center for Genome Technology at the University of Oklahoma has undertaken sequencing of cDNA clones isolated from 4 Amblyomma americanum salivary gland libraries:
TSG1, female, salivary gland, 50-200 mg feeding adults
TSG2, female, salivary gland, unfed adults, feeding adults, replete adults
TSG3, female, salivary gland, 3 day feeding adults
TSG4, female, salivary gland, 50-200 mg feeding adults

The data hase been submitted to EST division of GenBank in 2003.
bioproject.organization: University of Oklahoma's Advanced Center for Genome Technology

bioproject.title: Reference sequence (RefSeq) of the Anopheles gambiae genome
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence (RefSeq) A. gambiae genome is provided by NCBI and based on the submission from The Anopheles Genome Sequencing Consortium. The genome can be viewed in NCBI's Map Viewer browser.

For additional information, please see the RefSeq chapter in the NCBI Handbook.

bioproject.organism: Drosophila melanogaster strain:y; cn bw sp
bioproject.title: Reference sequences (RefSeq) of the Drosophila melanogaster genome
bioproject.description:
The NCBI reference sequence (RefSeq) for the D. melanogaster genome is based on the annotated genome submission from the FlyBase Consortium. The genome can be viewed in NCBI's Map Viewer browser. The RefSeq records incorporate some additional name information that is separately provided by FlyBase.

For additional information, please see the RefSeq chapter in the NCBI Handbook.

bioproject.title: Honey bee brain expressed sequence tag (EST) project
bioproject.description: The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign has carried out a sequencing program to study gene expression in Apis mellifera ligustica (common honey bee). Over 20,000 cDNA clones were partially sequenced from the normalized and subtracted libraries at the Keck Center, resulting in 15,311 vector-trimmed, high-quality, sequences. These sequences were assembled into 8966 putatively unique sequences, which were tested for similarity to sequences in the public databases with a variety of BLAST searches.
bioproject.organization: Department of Entomology and Neuroscience Program, University of Illinois, Urbana

bioproject.title: 8.2x WGS sequencing and assembly led by DOE Joint Genome Institute
bioproject.description: The Ciona intestinalis genome was sequenced at 8.2X coverage using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) strategy and assembled with the JAZZ suite of assembly tools. The assembly is a combination of the maternal and paternal haplotypes, which differ by about 1.2%. The assembly contains 116.7 million base pairs of nonrepetitive sequence, which represents about 75% of the C. intestinalis genome. It is estimated that 95% of protein-coding genes are contained in the assembly. Version 2 of the assembly is available at JGI but it has not been submitted to GenBank.

bioproject.title: Danio rerio mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The 16,596 nucleotide mitochondrial genome of zebrafish (Danio rerio) has been determined. Gene order and content are identical among zebrafish and the majority of known vertebrate mitochondrial genomes.

bioproject.title: RefSeq annotation of the human reference genome assembly
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is provided by NCBI using assembly instructions provided by the International Human Genome Project. The assembled genome is distributed internationally by FTP and the same assembly can be viewed in browsers provided by NCBI, Ensembl, and the University of Santa Cruz (UCSC).

The reference genome is annotated using an evidence-based approach that interprets ab initio predictions (About) in the context of alignment results of a) curated RefSeq records that are maintained independently of the genome annotation process; b)cDNA and EST transcript data; c) protein sequence data.

For additional information please see:

  • NCBI Handbook:
    • Genome Pipeline chapter
    • RefSeq chapter
  • Genome assembly documentation
  • RefSeq web site
  • Map Viewer

bioproject.title: RefSeq annotation of the mouse reference genome assembly.
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is provided by NCBI using assembly instructions provided by the Genome Reference Consortium. The assembled genome is distributed internationally by FTP and the same assembly can be viewed in browsers provided by NCBI, Ensembl, and the University of Santa Cruz (UCSC).

The reference genome is annotated using an evidence-based approach that interprets ab initio predictions (About) in the context of alignment results of a) curated RefSeq records that are maintained independently of the genome annotation process; b) cDNA and EST transcript data; c) protein sequence data.

For additional information please see:

  • NCBI Handbook:
    • Genome Pipeline chapter
    • RefSeq chapter
  • Genome assembly documentation
  • RefSeq web site
  • Map Viewer

bioproject.title: Causes glanders and pneumonia
bioproject.description: Burkholderia mallei strain ATCC 23344. This type strain (ATCC 23344; NBL 7; China 7; 3873; EY 2233; RH627) came from a Chinese patient in Burma who had glanders in 1944. The genome of this organism carries a large number of insertion sequences as compared to the related Bukholderia pseudomallei, and a large number of simple sequence repeats that may function in antigenic variation of cell surface proteins.

bioproject.title: Nitrate-reducing hyperthermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Pyrobaculum aerophilum strain IM2. This organism was isolated from a boiling marine water hole in Maronti Beach, Ischia, Italy. It grows optimally a 100ºC and pH 7.0. Growth can occur at temperatures between 74 and 104 ºC.

bioproject.title: Type strain that causes bacterial endocarditis
bioproject.description: Streptococcus mitis strain NCTC 12261. This strain is the type strain of this species.

bioproject.title: Causes necrotizing periodontal disease
bioproject.description: Prevotella intermedia strain 17. This strain is a clinical isolate from a human periodontal pocket and produces a different type of fimbriae as compared to other strains.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of a wide range of infections of the urogenital and respiratory tracts.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma penetrans strain HF-2. This strain has been isolated from the tracheal aspirate of a previously healthy HIV-negative patient with severe respiratory symptoms caused by this infection.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic motile microbe capable of reducing iron and uranium
bioproject.description: Geobacter metallireducens strain GS-15. First isolated from the Potomac river downstream of Washington, DC in 1987. This organism actively moves towards metal attractants such as iron and manganese oxides, which are insoluble, and produces type IV pili for attachment to the insoluble substrates.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes melioidosis
bioproject.description: Burkholderia pseudomallei strain K96243. This strain was a clinical isolate from Thailand. The genome of this organism carries many genomic islands as compared to the related organism B. mallei, suggesting extensive horizontal transfer. Three different type III secretion systems (TTSS) are encoded on the chromosomes of this organism, two of which are similar to plant pathogenic TTSSs, while the third is similar to the Salmonella pathogenicity island, all of which may contribute to pathogenicity. Other virulence determinants include multidrug efflux pumps, secreted toxins and proteases, and various adhesins. Capsular polysaccharide may protect the organism from host defense mechanisms. This organism also carries a number of small sequence repeats which may promoter antigenic variation, similar to what was found with the B. mallei genome.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic hyperthermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Pyrococcus abyssi strain GE5. This organism was isolated from an active chimney in the North Fiji Basin of the Pacific Ocean at a depth of 3500 meters.

bioproject.title: Causes brucellosis and undulant fever
bioproject.description: Brucella melitensisstrain 16M. This strain was isolated from an infected goat and is pathogenic in humans.

bioproject.title: Causes proliferative enteropathy in animals
bioproject.description: Lawsonia intracellularis PHE/MN1-00. Lawsonia intracellularis PHE/MN1-00 was isolated from intestinal mucosal lesions in pigs that had proliferative enteropathy (PE). When introduced into health pigs, this organism produced the clinical and histological signs of PE.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of Wilt and Tuber Rot in potato
bioproject.description: Clavibacter michiganensis subsp. sepedonicus strain ATCC 33113. This organism was first described and classified in 1914 as "Bacterium sepedonicus" and is considered a major plant pathogen. It is a phytopathogenic actinomycete that causes wilt and tuber rot in potato, which is a plant vascular disease with very high bacterial titers. Pathogenicity is believed to be associated with the presence of two plasmids, pCSL1 and pCSL2.

bioproject.title: Causes hepatitis, typhlitis, hepatocellular tumors, and gastric bowel disease
bioproject.description: Helicobacter hepaticus strain ATCC 51449. This organism was found to be linked to an increasing incidence of liver tumors in mouse colonies at the National Cancer Institute in 1992. Normally it resides in the lower intestines, but it can cause chronic hepatitis. This organism has a similar urease gene cluster and cytolethal distending toxin as compared to Helicobacter pylori, but lacks other virulence factors such as the vacuolating cytotoxin and the cag pathogenicity island. However, it does contain a pathogenicity island that encodes proteins similar to those found in a type IV secretion system.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing of strain ATCC 20542 by Microbia
bioproject.description: Microbia sequenced the Aspergillus terreus strain ATCC 20542 genome using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing to identify genes with expression patterns that associate with secondary metabolite production.

bioproject.title: Soil-dwelling producer of anti-parasitic agent avermectin and other secondary metabolites.
bioproject.description: Streptomyces avermitilis strain MA-4680. This strain (ATCC 31267) was isolated and characterized in 1978 by R. Burg and colleagues from a soil sample collected in Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan.

bioproject.title: Food and waterborn pathogen that causes gastroenteritis
bioproject.description: Yersinia enterocolitica (type 0:8) strain 8081. This isolate (strain 8081; NCTC 13174) is a mouse-lethal serotype of Yersinia enterocolitica that contains a high pathogenicity island (HPI) that encodes an iron uptake system (yersiniabactin) and a type II secretion system.

bioproject.title: The Joint Genome Institute has sequenced this diatom to an estimated 14 fold depth
bioproject.description:
Thalassiosira pseudonana, a marine centric diatom, was sequenced using the whole genome sequence approach.

The Thalassiosira pseudonana CCMP 1335 genome is approximately 34 Mb in size. The Joint Genome Institute has sequenced the nuclear genome, as well as the plastid and mitochondrial genomes of this unicellular algae.

bioproject.title: Metal-reducing microorganism
bioproject.description: Geobacter sulfurreducens strain PCA. This strain was isolated from surface sediments of a hydrocarbon-contaminated ditch in Norman, Oklahoma. It oxidizes acetate to carbon dioxide and water while reducing compounds such as sulfur, fumarate, and various metals such as iron oxides (Fe(III)). Contains a large number of cytochrome c-type oxidases which contribute to the flexibility of this organism's electron transport network. Some of these proteins are important intermediates in electron transfer to the insoluble iron (III) oxides. This organism also contains chemotaxis and flagellar genes, suggesting it may become motile like Geobacter metallireducens.

bioproject.title: Produces botulinum, one of the most potent toxins known
bioproject.description: Clostridium botulinum A str ATCC 3502. This strain is a well-studied Hall strain that produces type A toxin.

bioproject.title: Project to sequence approximately 20,000 cDNAs from the tsetse fly
bioproject.description: The Wellcome Trust has funded an EST sequencing project at the Pathogen Sequencing Unit of The Sanger Institute, in collaboration with Professor Mike Lehane at University of Wales, Bangor. Approximately 20,000 cDNAs from an infected midgut cDNA library of Glossina morsitans morsitans (Tsetse Fly) will be sequenced. The Tsetse fly is the vector for the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, the causal agent of African sleeping sickness in humans and Nagana in cattle.

bioproject.title: Causes bacillary angiomatosis
bioproject.description: Bartonella henselae str. Houston-1. Bartonella henselae str. Houston-1 (ATCC 49882) was isolated from human blood in Houston Texas.

bioproject.title: Causes a fibrinous and necrotizing pleuropneumonia
bioproject.description: Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae serovar 1 strain 4074. This is a virulent serovar (serotype) to be used in comparative genomic studies.

bioproject.title: Acidophilic extreme thermophile
bioproject.description: Acidianus brierleyi. This organism will be used for comparative genome analysis.

bioproject.title: Causes a fibrinous and necrotizing pleuropneumonia
bioproject.description: Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae serovar 5. This is a virulent serovar (serotype) to be used in comparative genomic studies.

bioproject.title: Whole chromosome shotgun (WCS) sequencing, assembly, and annotation project
bioproject.description:
Dictyostelium discoideum was the first free-living protozoan to have its genome fully sequenced. Assembly, gene prediction, and annotation of the complete genome will allow for comparative genomic studies that will facilitate identification of homologous genes and further the understanding of this model organism as well as of other protozoa.

Sequencing of the 34-Mb haploid genome of D. discoideum was undertaken on a chromosome-by-chromosome basis through an international consortium of laboratories and sequencing centers. Each chromosome was individually shotgun cloned, assembled, and annotated. The six chromosomes of this organism encode approximately 12,500 predicted proteins, a large proportion of which have long stretches of repetitive amino acid sequences. In addition to the nuclear genome, D. discoideum has a 55-kb mitochondrial genome and several copies of extrachromosomal elements that contain the rDNA genes.

The D. discoideum strain AX4 whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the accession AAFI00000000. Version 2 of the WGS project was updated in August 2009.

bioproject.title: Psychrophilic crenarchaeon symbiont
bioproject.description:
Cenarchaeum symbiosum A. This population was derived from assembled contigs.

Genbank sequences from Cenarchaeum symbiosum A can be accessed under accessions DQ397540-DQ397640, for the contigs, and under DP000238 for the complete genome.

bioproject.title: Causes corn stunt disease
bioproject.description: Spiroplasma kunkelii strain CR2-3x . This strain was originally isolated from maize leaves from a plant naturally infected in Costa Rica.

bioproject.title: Unusual gram negative bacterium that has glycosphingolipid instead of lipopolysaccharide and can degrade a wide variety of aromatic hydrocarbons
bioproject.description: Novosphingobium aromaticivorans strain DSM 12444. This strain, also known as F199, was isolated from a sample obtained at a depth of 410 m from a borehole sample that was drilled at the Savannah River Site in South Carolina, USA, by the Department of Energy.

bioproject.title: Degrades chlorinated pollutants
bioproject.description: Desulfitobacterium hafniense strain DCB-2. This is the type strain for this species and has been isolated from municipal sludge. It can dechlorinate chlorinated phenolic compounds such as PCBs and some pesticides.

bioproject.title: Thermoacidophilic archaea
bioproject.description: Thermoplasma volcanium strain GSS1. This strain is the type strain for this species, and was isolated from a solfataric (volcanic area that gives off sulfuric gases) field.
bioproject.organization: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan

bioproject.title: Anaerobic hyperthermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Pyrococcus horikoshii strain OT3. This organism was isolated from a hydrothermal vent at Okinawa Trough in the Pacific Ocean at a depth of 1395 m.

bioproject.title: Extreme hyperthermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Hyperthermus butylicus DSM 5456. This organism was isolated from the sea floor of a solfataric (volcanic area that gives off gas) environment with temperatures up to 112°C at a depth of 9 m, off the shore of Sao Miguel Island, Azores.

bioproject.title: Sequence of all three chromosomes of the Guillardia theta Nucleomorph
bioproject.description:
The reference sequence (Refseq) of G. theta nucleomorph is provided by the NCBI. It is a copy of the genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Institute for Marine Biosciences, Halifax, Canada.

For additional information, please see the RefSeq Project chapter in the NCBI Handbook.

bioproject.title: Aerobic hyperthermophilic archaeon
bioproject.description: Aeropyrum pernix strain K1. This organism, which was the first strictly aerobic hyperthermophilic archaeon sequenced, was isolated from a coastal solfataric (volcanic hydrothermal area that gives off sulfuric gases) thermal vent at Kodakara-Jima Island, Japan in 1993.

bioproject.organism: Leifsonia xyli subsp. xyli str. CTCB07
bioproject.title: Causative agent of ratoon stunting disease in sugarcane.
bioproject.description: Leifsonia xyli strain CTCB07. This strain is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.organism: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. pastoris str. CCMP1986
bioproject.title: Smallest and most abundant bacterium that has unique photosynthesizing components
bioproject.description: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1986. This high-light adapted strain is also known as strain MED4 or CCMP1378.

bioproject.title: Reduces chlorinated hydrocarbons in contaminated subsurface environments.
bioproject.description: Dehalococcoides ethenogenes strain 195. This strain is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic organism that is one of the deepest branching organism
bioproject.description: Aquifex aeolicus strain VF5. The genome sequence of this organism will provide information on the mechanisms involved in survival at high temperatures.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing cyanobacterium
bioproject.description: Nostoc punctiforme strain ATCC 29133. The strain was isolated from a symbiotic association with the gymnosperm cycad Macrozamia sp. (Rippka and Herdman, 1992). It typically grows in freshwater habitats.

bioproject.title: Chemoheterotrophic obligate extreme halophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Halobacterium sp. strain NRC-1. This microbe (strain ATCC 700922) is an obligately halophilic archeon that has adapted to growth under conditions of extremely high salinity. Motility is via tufts of polar flagella and intracellular gas vesicles are used for buoyancy. This organism grow aerobically and its ease of culturing combined with the availability of established methods of genetic manipulation in the laboratory make it an ideal model organism for study of the archaea.
bioproject.organization: University of Massachusetts-Amherst, University of Washington

bioproject.title: Human-specific organism that causes a variety of diseases (avirulent strain)
bioproject.description: Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd. This nontypeable strain is also known as KW20. It lacks an important fimbrial gene cluster that is important for virulence as compared to type b strains and was the first microbe to ever be sequenced.

bioproject.title: Smallest and most abundant bacterium that has unique photosynthesizing components
bioproject.description: Prochlorococcus marinus str. MIT 9313. Low light-adapted strain.

bioproject.title: Causes major respiratory disease in cattle
