bioproject.description: Mannheimia haemolytica PHL213. Mannheimia haemolytica PHL213 is a serotype 1 strain isolated from the lung of a calf with pneumonia.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of tuberculosis.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain CDC1551. This strain, also nicknamed "Oshkosh", is a recent clinical isolate from a clothing factory worker from the Kentucky/Tennessee, USA, region. It is highly contagious, infecting approximately 80% of the patient's social contacts. However, this strain has not caused epidemics in man and is sensitive to a wide range of drugs. It is also highly virulent in a mouse lung model, producing several orders of magnitude more bacteria than the H37Rv strain when inoculated.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of tuberculosis.
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain H37RV. This strain has been derived from the original human-lung H37 isolate in 1934, and has been used extensively worldwide in biomedical research. Unlike some clinical isolates, it retains full virulence in animal models of tuberculosis and is susceptible to drugs and receptive to genetic manipulation.

bioproject.organism: Escherichia coli str. K-12 substr. MG1655
bioproject.title: Model organism for genetics, physiology, biochemistry
bioproject.description: Escherichia coli strain K-12 substrain MG1655. Non-pathogenic strain MG1655 approximates wild-type E. coli as it has been maintained with very little genetic manipulation except for the curing (removal) of bacteriophage lambda and the F plasmid. MG1655 was derived from strain W1485, which was derived by Joshua Lederberg from the original K-12 isolate obtained from a patient in 1922.

bioproject.title: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli
bioproject.description:
Escherichia coli O157:H7. This strain is associated with Hamburger disease, which is caused by the contamination of meat products by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The identifier O157:H7 refers to the serotype of EHEC, and reflects the specific antigenic markers found on the surface of the cell. EHEC attaches and effaces to cells in the large intestine.

There are numerous differences that distinguish O157:H7 from K-12, hundreds of them associated with genomic islands in either strain, including at least 9 large PAIs in O157:H7 that encode virulence factors. A type III secretion system, the locus of enterocyte effacement, numerous toxins and adhesins, as well as fimbrial gene clusters and iron uptake systems are found in these PAIs. Pathogenicity genes are also found on the plasmid pO157.

Escherichia coli O157:H7 strain Sakai. This strain of O157:H7 was isolated in a 1997 outbreak in Sakai, Japan.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila caviae GPIC. Chlamydophila caviae GPIC, formerly Chlamydophila psittaci, is a guinea pig inclusion conjunctivitis strain.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description:
.

Chlamydia muridarum Nigg. This is a wild-type strain that is virulent in mice.

bioproject.title: Marine cyanobacteria
bioproject.description: Synechococcus sp. WH 8102. This strain is a motile strain that can be grown in both natural and artificial seawater liquid media. It was isolated from the tropical Atlantic ocean in 1981. The genome contains evidence of many phage integration events and analysis of the metabolic pathways show that this organism is capable of a more nutritionally diverse lifestyle than that of Prochlorococcus.

bioproject.title: Causes gastric inflammation and peptic ulcer disease
bioproject.description: Helicobacter pylori strain 26695. This strain was originally isolated from a patient in the United Kingdom who had gastritis before 1987, this strain has undergone repeated subculturing prior to being sequenced.

bioproject.title: Causes gastric inflammation and peptic ulcer disease
bioproject.description: Helicobacter pylori strain J99. This strain was isolated in 1994 in the USA from a patient with duodenal ulcer. It has undergone little subculturing prior to being sequenced.

bioproject.title: Alkaliphilic organism used in the industrial production of ß-galactosidase and xylanase
bioproject.description: Bacillus halodurans strain C-125. Strain C-125 (JCM9153) was isolated in 1977 and is the most well studied alkaliphilic Bacillus organism. The genome contains many transposase genes, suggesting extensive horizontal gene transfer. Several key competence genes are missing, indicating that taking DNA up from the environment may be impaired in this organism.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi str. CT18
bioproject.title: Human-specific Salmonella that causes Typhoid fever
bioproject.description:
Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi. This serovar is a human-specific organism that causes the life-threatening illness Typhoid fever which is acquired by coming into contact with contaminated food or water. Annually, 17 million people are infected, with 600,000 fatalities, mostly in developing countries. It contains multiple fimbrial operons that may be used to create extracellular appendages for attachment and entry into host intestinal epithelial cells.

Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi strain CT18. This strain is a multidrug resistant strain of Salmonella typhi. It contains a large number of pseudogenes as compared to related organisms. CT18 also has two plasmids, pHCM1 and pHCM2, which mediate drug resistance and may also encode virulence functions.

bioproject.title: Typical laboratory strain
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain NCTC 8325. This strain was originally used as a propagating strain for bacteriophage 47 of the international typing set of bacteriophages. This strain is generally considered to be the prototypical strain for most genetic research on S. aureus. Source DNA is available from www.narsa.net
bioproject.organization: University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center

bioproject.title: Methicillin resistant strain
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain COL. This strain is a methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strain and is also resistant to several other antibiotics including penicillin and tetracycline.

bioproject.title: Acidophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Ferroplasma acidarmanus fer1. This organism was isolated in 1997 from slime streamers and attached to pyrite surfaces at a sulfide ore body in Iron Mountain, California.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Dublin
bioproject.title: Bovine-adapted Salmonella
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Dublin. This is a bovine-adapted serovar that is genetically related to S. Enteritidis that lives in the bovine intestinal tract and can causes disease in humans.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
bioproject.title: Major laboratory strain of Salmonella typhimurium
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain LT2. This strain was first isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity. It became the principle laboratory strain and many important biochemical and genetic experiments were performed using this strain, including classical phage transduction studies. LT2 contains a plasmid, pSLT, that encodes additional virulence functions. Numerous prophages, some of which contain virulence genes, are inserted into the chromosome of LT2 as compared to related Salmonella.

bioproject.title: Soil-dwelling producer of antibiotics and other secondary metabolites.
bioproject.description: Streptomyces coelicolor strain A3(2) M145. This strain is a derivative of the laboratory strain A3(2) lacking its two plasmids SCP1 and SCP2 which were sequenced separately after being isolated from the original strain A3(2).

bioproject.title: Fusarium graminearum PH-1 RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly (see linked project PRJNA13839). Annotation on the RefSeq genomic records is propagated from the INSDC submission. RefSeq records may differ from the submitted annotation in format details, some protein names, and occasionally in feature location details.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria that also produce a variety of cyanotoxins
bioproject.description:
fixation.

Nostoc sp. PCC7120. Also known as Anabaena sp. PCC7120 this strain is wild-type. It differs from closely related Anabaena variabilis ATCC 29413 in that the heterocyst formation system has a programmed gene rearrangement at the hupL locus.

bioproject.title: Primary endosymbiont of the Acyrthosiphon pisum aphid
bioproject.description: Buchnera sp. APS. This strain is found in the pea aphid, Acyrthosiphon pisum. Its genome consists of one circular chromosome and two small plasmids pLeu and pTrp.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic acidophilic sulfur metabolizing archeon
bioproject.description: Sulfolobus tokodaii strain 7. This organism was isolated from Beppu Hot Springs in the geothermal area of Kyushu Island, Japan.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain AR39. Isolated from a University of Washington student with acute respiratory (=AR) tract infection in 1983, and epidemiologically distinct from Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain CWL029.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain CWL029. Isolated in the USA before 1987 and epidemiologically distinct from Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain AR39.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic eubacterium
bioproject.description: Thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis strain MB4. This organism was originally isolated from a hot spring in Tengcong, China, and is the type strain for the species. Genomic analysis indicates it is similar to Bacillus halodurans and that it has one of the most biased leading strand distribution of genes. Although the organism has not been observed to be motile or to sporulate, it does contain genes for both functions. The bacterium produces acetate and ethanol from glucose and cannot degrade xylan and cellulose.

bioproject.title: Extremely metal resistant bacterium
bioproject.description: Cupriavidus metallidurans CH34. This strain was first identified in the heavy metal-contaminated sludge of a settling tank in Belgium in the late 1970s. Metal resistance functions are predominantly encoded on two plasmids, pMOL28 and pMOL30, which produce metal exporters that pump metal ions out of the cell, thus protecting intracellular macromolecules from the toxic effects of high concentrations of metal.

bioproject.title: Causes meningitis and septicemia
bioproject.description: Neisseria meningitidis serogroup B strain MC58. The B serogroup is responsible for many of the meningitis outbreaks in the developed world. This strain was isolated from a case of invasive infection.

bioproject.title: Causes meningitis and septicemia
bioproject.description: Neisseria meningitidis strain Z2491. This is a serogroup A strain isolated in Gambia in 1983.

bioproject.title: Hyperthermophilic bacterium that can grow on carbon monoxide
bioproject.description: Carboxydothermus hydrogenoformans strain Z-2901. This strain was isolated from a hot swamp from Kunashir Island, Russia.

bioproject.title: Biodegrades polychlorinated biphenyls
bioproject.description: Burkholderia xenovorans strain LB400. Originally identified as Pseudomonas sp. LB400 that was found in contaminated soil in upstate New York, this organism is now classified in the genus Burkholderia. This is the type strain and is being sequenced for studies in comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Causes meningitis and septicemia
bioproject.description: Neisseria meningitidis FAM18. Strain FAM18 is a member of the serogroup C ET-37 complex and was isolated from a patient with meningococcal septicemia.

bioproject.title: Primary endosymbiont of the Baizongia pistaciae aphid
bioproject.description: Buchnera aphidicola strain Bp (Baizongia pistaciae). This organism is found in the aphid Baizongia pistaciae and contains a large circular chromosome and an additional plasmid, pBBp1.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain J138. Isolated in Japan in 1994 from the pharyngeal mucosa of a 5 year old male patient with acute bronchitis.

bioproject.title: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli
bioproject.description:
Escherichia coli O157:H7. This strain is associated with Hamburger disease, which is caused by the contamination of meat products by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The identifier O157:H7 refers to the serotype of EHEC, and reflects the specific antigenic markers found on the surface of the cell. EHEC attaches and effaces to cells in the large intestine.

There are numerous differences that distinguish O157:H7 from K-12, hundreds of them associated with genomic islands in either strain, including at least 9 large PAIs in O157:H7 that encode virulence factors. A type III secretion system, the locus of enterocyte effacement, numerous toxins and adhesins, as well as fimbrial gene clusters and iron uptake systems are found in these PAIs. Pathogenicity genes are also found on the plasmid pO157.

Escherichia coli O157:H7 strain EDL933. This strain (substrain) is considered a reference strain of O157:H7, which was first isolated during an outbreak in 1982.

bioproject.title: Almond tree-specific phytopathogen
bioproject.description: Xylella fastidiosa strain Dixon. This strain is an almond tree-specific strain.

bioproject.title: Oleander-specific phytopathogen
bioproject.description: Xylella fastidiosa Ann-1. This strain is an oleander-specific (poisonous evergreen shrub) phytopathogen.

bioproject.title: Magnetotactic bacterium
bioproject.description: Magnetococcus sp. MC-1. This magnetotactic bacterium was isolated from water from the Pettaquamscutt Estuary, in Rhode Island, USA. Migration is towards the anoxic/oxic interface which in the case of Magnetococcus sp. MC-1 is in a polar direction. The genome sequence of this organism will provide information on the production and regulation of the proteins involved in the magnetosome.

bioproject.title: Methicillin and vancomycin resistant strain
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain Mu50. This strain is a methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strain with vancomycin resistance (VRSA) isolated in 1997 from the pus of a Japanese male baby with a surgical wound infection that did not respond to vancomycin.

bioproject.title: Methicillin resistant strain
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain N315. This strain is a methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strain isolated in 1982 from a pharyngeal smear of a Japanese patient.

bioproject.title: Methicillin resistant strain from the UK
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain 252. This strain is a hospital-acquired strain isolated in the United Kingdom, representative of the methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strains. It is one of the two major MRSA strains found in British hospitals in the late 1990's.

bioproject.title: Methicillin sensitive strain from the UK
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain 476. This strain is a hyper-virulent community acquired methicillin-susceptible (MSSA) strain isolated in the United Kingdom.

bioproject.title: Microbe involved in putrefaction
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas putida strain KT2440. This strain was derived from a toluene-degrading isolate, Pseudomonas arvilla strain mt-2 (renamed Pseudomonas putida mt-2), by loss of its plasmid. It is the best characterized saprophytic bacteria, and the choice for cloning and gene expression in Gram-negative bacteria and can survive in the general environment (outside the laboratory). It is used in the development of biopesticides and is the first Gram-negative soil bacterium to be certified as a safety strain by the Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee.

bioproject.title: Microorganism of putrefaction
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas putida strain PRS1. This is the type strain for this organism and has been used extensively in the laboratory.

bioproject.title: Group A Streptococcus that causes a wide variety of infections
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pyogenes strain M1 GAS. This strain is also known as group A streptococci (GAS). This organism is a strict human pathogen that was isolated from a patient with a wound infection.

bioproject.title: Serotype M5 strain associated with rheumatic fever
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pyogenes strain Manfredo. This strain is a serotype M5 strain associated with acute rheumatic fever isolated from a patient in the 1950's in Chicago.

bioproject.title: Citrus-specific phytopathogen
bioproject.description: Xylella fastidiosa strain 9a5c. This strain was derived from a pathogenic strain (8.1b) isolated in 1992 in France that had come from infected twigs derived from the sweet orange strain Valencia in Brazil in the same year.

bioproject.title: Obligate endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster that affects host reproduction
bioproject.description: Wolbachia endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster. Wolbachia endosymbiont of Drosophila melanogaster, also known as Wolbachia pipentis strain wMel, naturally infects Drosophila melanogaster and is a member of supergroup A. The genome contains a large number of repetitive elements as well as proteins with ankyrin repeats that may be important in bacterium-host interactions. The chromosome also contains genes that encode a type IV secretion system.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of tuberculosis
bioproject.description: Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain 210. This strain was originally isolated during a tuberculosis outbreak in Texas, USA. It was subsequently found that this strain is one of the most wide-spread and virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

bioproject.organism: Wigglesworthia glossinidia endosymbiont of Glossina brevipalpis
bioproject.title: Obligate endosymbiont of the tsetse fly vector for African trypanosomes.
bioproject.description: Wigglesworthia glossinidia endosymbiont of Glossina brevipalpis. This organism is the obligate endosymbiont for the tsetse fly Glossina brevipalpis. As Wigglesworthia brevipalpis resides intracellularly, the resulting co-evolution with its host over millions of years has led to a drastic reduction in the bacterium's genome size, resulting in this its inability to survive outside the host. Its genome is one of the smallest genomes identified so far, which makes it an ideal candidate to study the evolutionary impact of obligate intracellular existence.

bioproject.title: Model cold-adapted bacterium
bioproject.description: Colwellia psychrerythraea strain 34H . This strain was isolated from Arctic marine sediments.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes important food-born disease
bioproject.description: Listeria monocytogenes strain EGD-e. This strain has numerous pathogenicity islands and genes as compared to the related non-pathogenic organism Listeria innocua. This strain is serovar 1/2a and is derived from the strain EGD that was used in studies of cell-mediated immunity.

bioproject.title: Causes pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pneumoniae strain TIGR4. This strain is a highly virulent capsular serotype 4 clinical isolate from the blood of a 30 year old male patient in Kongsvinger, Norway.

bioproject.title: Avirulent isolate
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pneumoniae strain R6. This strain is an avirulent descendent of a type 2 capsule S clinical isolate used by Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty to demonstrate the genetic function of DNA.

bioproject.title: Used for detection of residual antibiotics in food products
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus epidermidis strain ATCC 12228. This strain is a non-biofilm-forming, non-infection associated strain used for detection of residual antibiotics in food products.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. TR7095
bioproject.title: Causes food poisoning
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain TR7095. Preliminary sequence data for this wild-type strain was generated and deposited to NCBI for BLAST only searches (also available on their website) by WU-GSC. It is unknown if there are plans to completely sequence this organism.

bioproject.title: Degrades dimethylsulfoniopropionate in marine environments
bioproject.description: Ruegeria pomeroyi strain DSS-3. Formerly Silicibacter pomeroyi, his marine bacterium is a member of the Roseobacter clade and was isolated off of the coast of Georgia in 1998. DSS-3 is the type strain for this species. Analysis will provide insight into sulfur cycling by microbes in marine environments.

bioproject.title: Tumor-inducing bacterium which is used in genetic engineering of plants
bioproject.description: Agrobacterium tumefaciens strain C58. This strain is a biovar 1 nopaline-producing strain originally isolated from a cherry tree tumor. The genome consists of one circular and one linear chromsome and two plasmids, one of which is the conjugative Ti plasmid that transfers the T-DNA. This genome was sequenced by Cereon Genomics but ongoing work in the Agrobacterium genomics community has led to a merged record containing the Cereon sequence and merged annotation that is considered the gold standard comprised of annotation work at Cereon and the University of Washington.

bioproject.title: Extremely halotolerant bacterium
bioproject.description: Oceanobacillus iheyensis strain HTE831. This organism was isolated from deep sea mud (1050 m) from the Iheya ridge near Okinawa, Japan in 1998. Strain HTE831 is the type strain for this species.

bioproject.title: Phytopathogen that infects a wide range of plants
bioproject.description: Xylella fastidiosa strain Temecula1. This strain was isolated in 1998 from a naturally infected Californian grapevine.

bioproject.title: Serotype M18 strain associated with severe rheumatic fever outbreaks
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pyogenes strain MGAS8232. This strain is a serotype M18 strain often associated with acute rheumatic fever outbreaks in the USA.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic hyperthermophilic archeon
bioproject.description: Pyrococcus furiosus strain DSM 3638. This strain was isolated from a shallow marine solfataric (volcanic area that gives off sulfuric gases) region at Vulcano Island, Italy.

bioproject.title: Extremely virulent organism that causes plague
bioproject.description: Yersinia pestis strain KIM 10. This strain is a Medievalis subtype (biovar) that is widely used in research and is well characterized.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic methane-producing archaeon
bioproject.description: Methanothermobacter thermautotrophicus str. Delta H. This strain was isolated from sewage sludge in 1971 in Urbana, Illinois.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic methane-producing archeon
bioproject.description: Methanosarcina acetivorans C2A. This wild-type strain (C2A; DSM2834) is the type strain of this species and was isolated from marine sediment.

bioproject.title: Serotype 6B isolate
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pneumoniae strain 670-6B. This strain was isolated in 1988 from Spain and is a serotype 6B isolate.

bioproject.title: Causes leptospirosis
bioproject.description: Leptospira interrogans serovar Lai str. 56601. This strain has been maintained by the National Institute for Communicable Disease Control and Prevention, at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention in Beijing, China, and is a pathogenic strain.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic methanogenic archaeon
bioproject.description: Methanopyrus kandleri AV19. This organism is an obligately anaerobic hyperthermophilic archeon that was isolated from Guaymas hot vents in anaerobic seawater at a depth of 2000 m. The M. kandleri AV19 genome analysis reveals that this organism is a "minimalist" archaeon, with a small number of genes transferred from bacteria, low diversity of transporters, and particularly, an under representation of predicted regulatory proteins. The presence of such minimal gene set may be a reflection of the M. kandleri's extreme habitat, which could limit its ability to exchange genes with other organisms.

bioproject.title: Oral bacterium contributing to tooth decay.
bioproject.description: Fusobacterium nucleatum subsp. nucleatum ATCC25586. This strain is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.organism: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. ATCC 33913
bioproject.title: Plant-specific pathogen that causes black rot
bioproject.description: Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris str. ATCC 33913. This strain was originally isolated from cabbage. The genome contains 2 different type II secretion systems for the export of extracellular enzymes such as cellulases that degrade the plant cell wall. It contains a single type III secretion system (Hrp) that is important for pathogenicity and has genes that allow colonziation and systemic infection.

bioproject.title: Plant-specific pathogen that causes citrus canker
bioproject.description: Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. citri str. 306. This strain contains genes that are similar to genes from another citrus pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa. It has 2 different type II secretion system for the export of extracellular enzymes that degrade the plant cell wall including cellulases. The genome encodes a single type III secretion system (Hrp) that is important for pathogenicity as well as two type IV secretion system, one on the chromosome and one found on one of the two plasmids this organism contains, pXAC64.

bioproject.title: Bacterium that undergoes asymmetric cell division and differentiation
bioproject.description: Caulobacter crescentus strain CB15. This is a wild-type strain and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. A2012. This strain (Florida isolate, cat. A2012, Ames genotype) was isolated from a patient who suffered severe inhalational anthrax in 2001 from West Palm Beach, Florida. It was sequenced in conjunction with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's analysis of the letter attacks that occurred in 2001.

bioproject.title: Anaerobic methane-producing archeon
bioproject.description: Methanosarcina mazei Go1. Methanosarcina mazei Go1 (DSM 3647) was isolated from an anaerobic sewage digester in Germany.

bioproject.title: Serotype M3 strain isolated from toxic shock patient
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pyogenes strain SSI-1. This strain is a serotype M3 strain that was isolated from a toxic-shock patient in Japan and often associated with severe invasive infections, necrotizing fasciitis, and death.

bioproject.title: Photosynthetic thermophile that harvests light energy using a novel mechanism
bioproject.description: Chlorobium tepidum strain TLS. This green-sulfur bacterium is a thermophile and was isolated from a New Zealand high-sulfide hot spring. It is a model organism for studying this group of bacteria due to its ease of cultivation and transformability.

bioproject.title: Leading cause of food poisoning
bioproject.description: Campylobacter jejuni strain RM1221. This strain (RM1221; ATCC BAA-1062) was isolated from the skin of a retail chicken by the Produce Safety and Microbiology Research Unit (Western Regional Research Center, Albany, CA) and minimally passaged. This strain has unique features that distinguish it from Campylobacter jejuni strain NCTC 11168 including unique lipooligosaccharide, capsule, and other loci, as well as the ability to colonize chicken skin and other differences.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of gas gangrene.
bioproject.description: Clostridium perfringens strain ATCC 13124. This strain is a type A isolate and is also the type strain of the species. It is used as a quality control organism in clinical and laboratory diagnostics.

bioproject.title: Industrial amino acid producer.
bioproject.description: Corynebacterium efficiens strain YS-314. This is the type strain of C. efficiens isolated by researchers of Ajinomoto food company from soils at Kanagawa, Japan in the late 1980's. The strain can grow and produce glutamate at temperatures above up to 45 C in contrast to C. glutamicum that is only efficient at around 30 C. This feature is very beneficial for industrial applications, because less heat removal is required in fermenters to be used for cultivation of these bacteria.

bioproject.title: Methicillin resistant strain
bioproject.description: Staphylococcus aureus subsp. aureus strain MW2. This strain is a community-acquired methicillin-resistant (MSRA) strain and is one of the major pathogens causing community-acquired infections in the Midwestern USA. Several fatal infections were attributed to this strain in the late 1990's.

bioproject.title: Industrial producer of multiple amino acids
bioproject.description: Corynebacterium glutamicum strain ATCC 13032. This strain (previously known as Micrococcus glutamicus) is the original strain isolated in the late 1950's.

bioproject.title: Thermophilic cyanobacterium that contains an unusual number of type II introns
bioproject.description: Thermosynechococcus elongatus strain BP-1. This is a uniquely thermophilic unicellular cyanobacteria that was isolated from Beppu hot spring in Japan. It is obligately photoautotrophic. It contains a large number of heat shock proteins as well as an unusually large number of type II intron sequences. It has been used as a model organism due to the stability of its photsynthetic components at high temperature.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax  (avirulent derivative)
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. Ames. This well studied laboratory strain (Porton isolate) is not virulent due to the loss of the two plasmids, pXO1 and pXO2.

bioproject.title: Human-specific pathogen that causes endemic dysentery
bioproject.description: Shigella flexneri 2a str. 301. This strain was isolated in 1984 from a patient in Beijing, China. It is similar to pathogenic Escherichia coli except for the more numerous insertion sequences and contains a virulence plasmid (pCP301).

bioproject.title: Serotype M3 strain
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pyogenes strain MGAS315. This strain is a serotype M3 strain.

bioproject.title: Primary endosymbiont of the Schizaphis graminum aphid
bioproject.description: Buchnera aphidicola strain Sg (Schizaphis graminum). This strain is the symbiont of the aphid Schizaphis graminum and contains a large circular chromosome.

bioproject.title: Uropathogenic Escherichia coli
bioproject.description: Escherichia coli strain CFT073. This strain (CFT073; O6:K2:H1) is uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) one of the most common causes of non-hospital-acquired urinary tract infections. There are numerous important differences between EHEC and UPEC, namely the loss of specific virulence factors such as the type III secretion system and plasmid- and phage-associated PAIs. UPEC has gained fimbrial operons, including genes for production of Pap pili, as well as other virulence factors that allow it to colonize the urinary tract.

bioproject.title: Clostridium thermocellum ATCC 27405
bioproject.description: Clostridium thermocellum strain ATCC 27405 Degrader of crystalline cellulose. This strain is a well studied producer of endoglucanase and several restriction endonucleases

bioproject.title: Used in industrial food fermentations
bioproject.description: Leuconostoc mesenteroides subsp. mesenteroides strain ATCC 8293. This strain is resistant to the antibiotic vancomycin.

bioproject.title: Marine bacteria that degrade complex insoluble carbohydrates
bioproject.description: Saccharophagus degradans 2-40. This strain is a marine gamma-proteobacterium that was isolated from decaying Spartina alterniflora, a salt marsh cord grass, in the Chesapeake Bay, USA. Saccharophagus degradans 2-40 has been used to produce ethanol from plant material and may be useful for the production bioethanol.

bioproject.title: Used for secondary fermentation in wine production
bioproject.description: Oenococcus oeni strain PSU-1. This strain was isolated at Penn State University and is used commercially for malolactic fermentation in wines.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing cyanobacterium
bioproject.description: Trichodesmium erythraeum strain IMS101. Trichodesmium erythraeum strain IMS101 was isolated from the North Carolina coast in 1992 and grows in straight filaments. This organism is easily grown in the laboratory and as a result has been extensively studied particularly in regards to its ability to fix nitrogen.

bioproject.title: Causes periodontitis
bioproject.description: Tannerella forsythensis strain 92A2 . Tannerella forsythensis strain 92A2 was isolated from a human periodontal pocket in Massachusetts

bioproject.title: Causes brucellosis, infectious abortions, fevers
bioproject.description: Brucella suis strain 1330. A swine isolate and standard reference strain for biovar 1.

bioproject.title: Probiotic bacterium found in intestines of most animals and insects.
bioproject.description: Bifidobacterium longum strain DJO10A. This strain is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Causes pneumonia, arthritis, myocarditis, and reproductive problems
bioproject.description: Haemophilus somnus 129PT . This strain is an asymptomatic carrier strain that was serum-resistant.

bioproject.title: Causes plant rot
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas syringae pv. syringae strain B728a. This strain is the causal agent of brown spot disease on beans. This strain exhibits an epiphytic phase on plants that subsequently invades and causes disease. It was isolated from a snap bean leaflet in Wisconsin. It can also nucleate ice at temperatures above the freezing point.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. KrugerB. The Kruger B (GT87 (genotype 87) group B1) strain was isolated from Kruger National Park in South Africa. This strain is almost exclusively found in South Africa where periodic outbreaks of anthrax affect the wildlife populations in the park.

bioproject.title: Causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis
bioproject.description: Ehrlichia chaffeensis strain Arkansas. This strain is the first isolate of Ehrlichia chaffeensis, which was obtained from a patient on an army base in Arkansas in 1990.

bioproject.title: Serotype Ic strain
bioproject.description: Streptococcus agalactiae strain A909. This strain is serotype Ic.

bioproject.title: Saprophyte
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas fluorescens strain Pf-5. This strain can suppress the diseases caused by Rhizoctonia solani and Pythium ultimum which affect cotton plants. The production of a number of antibiotics (pyrrolnitrin, pyoluteorin, and 2,4-diacetylphloroglucinol) as well as the production of siderophores (which may affect the ability of competing organisms to obtain environmental iron) by this strain can inhibit phytopathogen growth such as the above-mentioned fungi. The genome of this organism contains a number of genes, estimated at 5.7 % of the chromosome, that encode proteins that are involved in secondary metabolism. A large number of repeat elements (REP) are also found in the genome in greater numbers than in related Pseudomonas spp.

bioproject.title: Probiotic bacterium found in intestines of most animals and insects.
bioproject.description: Bifidobacterium longum strain NCC2705. This strain was isolated from infant feces. The genome of this strain is being sequenced for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Bacterium capable of metal corrosion
bioproject.description: Desulfovibrio alaskensis strain G20. This organism is a spontaneous nalidixic acid-resistant derivative of a wild-type strain (G100A) that was isolated from an oil well corrosion site. It has been cured of a 2.3 Kb cryptic plasmid as well. This organism is one of the few extensively studied sulfate-reducing bacteria.

bioproject.title: Serotype V clinical isolate
bioproject.description: Streptococcus agalactiae strain 2603V/R. This strain is a serotype V clinical isolate and is the most common type amoung GBS-infected (group B streptococcal) non-pregnant adults.

bioproject.title: Causes opportunistic infections in humans
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas aeruginosa strain PA01. This strain contains one of the largest bacterial genomes ever sequenced which consists of a circular chromosome of 6,264,403 bp. It is the most widely used Pseudomonas aeruginosa laboratory strain.

bioproject.title: Causes a fibrinous and necrotizing pleuropneumonia
bioproject.description: Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae serovar 7. This is a virulent serovar (serotype) to be used in comparative genomic studies.

bioproject.title: Clincial isolate that is serotype C and causes caries
bioproject.description: Streptococcus mutans strain UA159. This strain is a serotype c strain isolated from a child with active dental caries in 1982.

bioproject.title: Serotype III strain that causes neonatal meningitis
bioproject.description: Streptococcus agalactiae strain NEM316. This strain is a serotype III strain isolated from a case of fatal septicemia. Type III is responsible for 80% of neonatal GBS (group B streptococcal) meningitis.

bioproject.title: May be used for bioremediation of chromium and uranium
bioproject.description: Shewanella oneidensis strain MR-1. This strain was isolated from Oneida lake in New York, USA. It contains one plasmid and one chromosome, both of which have a number of gene duplications. Many of the duplicated genes appear to be involved in energy transport and metabolism. The chromosome also encodes a wide array of cytochrome C-type oxidases, which may contribute to the ability of the organism to use diverse electron acceptors. Numerous prophages and insertion sequencese are found in the chromosome as well.

bioproject.title: Obligate intracellular pathogen that causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis
bioproject.description: Anaplasma phagocytophilum strain HZ. Isolated from a patient in New York, USA, in 1995.

bioproject.organism: Bacillus anthracis str. Western North America USA6153
bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. WesternNA. The Western North America (GT3 (genotype 3) group A1a) strain is the most common genotype in France and North America.

bioproject.title: Causes necrotizing pneumonia, chronic infections
bioproject.description: Burkholderia cepacia strain J2315. This strain is the index strain for transmission among CF patients in the UK and is a genomovar III strain of the ET12 lineage.

bioproject.title: Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli
bioproject.description: Escherichia coli042. This strain is to be used for comparative studies with related Escherichia and Shigella species and is an enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) that causes persistent diarrhea by colonizing the intestinal mucosa.

bioproject.title: Saprophyte
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas fluorescens strain SBW25. Strain SBW25 colonizes both plant leaves and roots where it promotes plant growth due to its non-pathogenic nature, its ability to produce antibiotics, and direct competition with other potential pathogens (especially near the roots).

bioproject.title: Streptomycin resistant symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria
bioproject.description: Rhizobium leguminosarum biovar viciae 3841. This biovar nodulates legumes in the Tribe Viciae (Vicia, Pisum, Lathyrus, Lens). This strain is a spontaneous streptomycin-resistant mutant of strain 300. The host-specificity and nitrogen fixation genes are carried on large plasmids (of which it has 6).

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. SL1344
bioproject.title: Causes food poisoning
bioproject.description: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain SL1344. This strain is a genetically marked subline of a calf-virulent isolate.

bioproject.title: Human-specific pathogen that causes endemic dysentery
bioproject.description: Shigella dysenteriae strain M131649. This strain was isolated from a patient in 1970 in Guatemala.

bioproject.title: Cause of endemic bacillary dysentery
bioproject.description: Shigella sonnei 53G. Isolated from 5 year old patient in Japan.

bioproject.title: Virulent capsular serotype 4 drug-resistant clinical isolate
bioproject.description: Streptococcus pneumoniae strain 23F. This strain (Spanish 23F-1) is a penicillin resistant serotype and is one of the most common drug-resistant strains isolated and is believed to have originated in Spain.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that affects immunocompromised patients, especially those with liver damage
bioproject.description: Vibrio vulnificus strain CMCP6. This strain is to be used for comparative studies.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of soft rot and blackleg of potato
bioproject.description: Pectobacterium atrosepticum strain SCRI1043. This strain (ATCC BAA-672) is a virulent blackleg isolated from the stem of a potato plant. Genome analysis indicates this organism can fix nitrogen as well as catabolize plant-produced opines. The chromosome also encodes an extensive array of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes such as pectinases as well as all 6 of the known secretion systems. This suggests extensive secretion of pathogenicity determinants such as the aforementioned degradative enzymes but also others such as avirulence proteins. Disruption of the type IV secretion system affected virulence as well, suggesting it is does not simply reflect an integrated plasmid in the chromosome.

bioproject.title: Reptile-specific Salmonella
bioproject.description: NCTC 12419 (ATCC 43975; culture collection SGSC:SARC11) is the type strain.

bioproject.title: Serotype 2 strain that produces suilysin
bioproject.description: Streptococcus suis strain P1/7. This strain is a serotype 2 strain which produces suilysin. Suilysin is believed to be an important virulence factor for Streptococcus suis infection.

bioproject.title: Clinical isolate that causes bovine mastitis
bioproject.description: Streptococcus uberis strain 0140J. This strain was isolated from a clinical bovine mastitis case.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of Whipple's disease.
bioproject.description: Tropheryma whipplei strain TW08/27. This strain was isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid a woman who had suffered severe weight loss in Germany. The patient had been treated with antibiotics followed by a year of no treatment prior to the sample being taken.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila abortus strain S26/3. Strain S26/3 was isolated from an enzootic (affecting animals in a specific geographical area) abortion case in sheep.

bioproject.title: Single colony isolate from a human isolate
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus plantarum strain WCFS1. This strain is a single colony isolate of NCIMB8826, which was originally isolated from human saliva.

bioproject.title: Intracellular pathogen that causes Sennetsu fever
bioproject.description: Neorickettsia sennetsu strain Miyayama. This organism was first described in 1953 in Japan as causing Sennetsu fever.

bioproject.organism: Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato str. DC3000
bioproject.title: Causes plant rot
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato strain DC3000. While pathogenic on Arabidopsis thaliana, it is mainly characterized as causing bacterial speck disease on tomato plants, which has a large economic impact. This organism is mainly endophytic and is a poor colonizes of plant surfaces but can multiply within the host. It is the model organism for the study of plant-pathogen interactions.

bioproject.title: Major cause of seafood-associated food poisoning
bioproject.description: Vibrio parahaemolyticus strain RIMD 2210633. This is a clinical strain isolated in 1996 in Osaka, Japan. It contains a type III secretion system which may enable colonization and penetration of the host intestinal epithelial layer, and possibly lead to septicemia. The genome contains multipe chromosomal rearrangements as compared to Vibrio cholerae. The organism also produces a hemolysin (thermostable direct hemolysin - TDH) that is particular to Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

bioproject.title: Rice Genome Project for ssp. indica by the Chinese Academy of Sciences
bioproject.description:
The Whole genome shotgun sequence from Oryza sativa ssp. indica has been generated at the Beijing Genomics Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Second draft sequence data has been deposited in DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank as AAAA00000000.

The genome is 466 Mb in size with an estimated 46,022 to 55,615 genes.
bioproject.organization: Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences

bioproject.title: EST sequencing
bioproject.description: The University of Oklahoma is sequencing 14,900 ESTs from Aspergillus nidulans strain FGSC-A26(biA1).

bioproject.title: Causes coccidiosis in domestic fowl
bioproject.description:
The Eimeria tenella Houghton strain genome sequencing project is coordinated by a consortium comprising Sanger Center, the Institute of Animal Health, (UK), the University of Sao Paolo and the Malaysia Genome Institute.

The E. tenella genome is about 60 MB in size, is comprised of 14 chromosomes and is being sequenced to 8X coverage using whole genome shotgun together with ~10,000 scaffolding BAC ends. The genome has been assembled into contigs and is presently in the process of annotation.

Genetic linkage mapping studies of E. tenella determined 16 linkage groups which define 12 chromosomes and a further 57 unlinked groups. This data was obtained from Shirley MW and Harvey DA, 2000 Genome Res. 10:1587-93, and is displayed in MapViewer.

A complementary sequencing effort is being carried out by the Genome Sequencing Center at the Washington University School of Medicine, Saint Louis. A total of 13,190 ESTs have been generated from this apicomplexan parasite.

In addition to those sequencing efforts, the complete E. tenella apicoplast genome sequence data has been generated and submitted to GenBank by Texas A&M University, Veterinary Pathobiology, USA.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila felis strain Fe/C-56. Chlamydophila felis strain Fe/C-56 was isolated from a cat with conjunctivitis. The genome sequence of this organism will provide information on the genetic adaptations due to host specificity.

bioproject.organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi str. Ty2
bioproject.title: Human-specific Salmonella that causes Typhoid fever
bioproject.description:
Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi. This serovar is a human-specific organism that causes the life-threatening illness Typhoid fever which is acquired by coming into contact with contaminated food or water. Annually, 17 million people are infected, with 600,000 fatalities, mostly in developing countries. It contains multiple fimbrial operons that may be used to create extracellular appendages for attachment and entry into host intestinal epithelial cells.

Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhi strain Ty2. This pathogenic strain of Salmonella typhi was isolated in the early 1970s. It contains no multidrug resistance plasmids and has been used for vaccine development.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by the Broad Institute as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute conducted a comparative genomic analysis of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces mikatae. They produced a high-quality draft sequence of the Saccharomyces mikatae strain IFO 1815 genome at 5.9X sequence coverage using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach. The assembly, which represents approximately 93% of the Saccharomyces mikatae genome, consists of 1,648 contigs. The WGS sequences have been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AABZ00000000.

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing plant symbiont
bioproject.description: Gluconacetobacter diazotrophicus strain PAL5. Gluconacetobacter diazotrophicus strain PAL5 (ATCC 49037) was isolated from sugarcane roots in Brazil and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Soil organism that causes opportunistic infections such as food poisoning
bioproject.description: Bacillus cereus strain ATCC 14579. This is the Type strain for Bacillus cereus.

bioproject.title: Causes opportunistic infections in humans
bioproject.description: Pseudomonas aeruginosa strain UCBPP-PA14. This strain is a human clinical isolate from a human burn patient. It is infectious in mice, Caenorhabditis elegans, Drosophila melanogaster, and Arabidopsis thaliana. It is an excellent model for the study of pathogenesis and biofilm formation.

bioproject.title: Causes pneumonia, arthritis, myocarditis, and reproductive problems
bioproject.description: Haemophilus somnus 2336 . This strain was isolated from the lung of a calf which had pneumonia.

bioproject.title: An industrially important lactic acid bacteria.
bioproject.description: Pediococcus pentosaceus ATCC 25745. This is the wild-type strain.

bioproject.title: Dominant member of mammalian intestinal microflora
bioproject.description: Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron strain VPI-5482. This is the type strain for this organism and was isolated from the feces of a healthy adult.
bioproject.organization: Washington University Department of Molecular Biology and Pharmacology

bioproject.title: Used extensively in hard cheese production
bioproject.description:
Lactococcus lactis subsp. cremoris . This subspecies is used to make hard cheeses.

Lactococcus lactissubsp. cremoris SK11. This strain is recognized for the beneficial flavors it produces during cheese production.

bioproject.title: Starter culture for milk fermentation and flavor development of cheese
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus casei ATCC 334. This strain was isolated from Emmental cheese and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.organism: Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. bulgaricus ATCC BAA-365
bioproject.title: Thermophilic starter culture for yogurt and Swiss and Italian-type cheeses
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp.bulgaricus strain ATCC BAA-365. This strain was derived from an existing strain (derived from a French starter culture; CHCC757).

bioproject.title: Starter culture for beer, soudough, and silage
bioproject.description: Lactobacillus brevis ATCC 367. Lactobacillus brevis ATCC 367 will be used for comparative analysis with other lactic acid bacteria.

bioproject.title: Brevibacterium aurantiacum strain:BL2 Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description: Bacterium used in cheddar cheese ripening processes.  This strain is a well-studied and widely used industrial strain of the species.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that is a major cause of hospital-acquired infections
bioproject.description: Serratia marcescens strain Db11. A non-pigmented strain that was isolated from Drosophila that was spontaneously resistant to streptomycin.

bioproject.title: Human-specific pathogen that causes endemic dysentery
bioproject.description: Shigella flexneri 2a str. 2457T. This is a highly virulent strain that has been widely used for genetic and clinical research. It is similar to pathogenic Escherichia coli except for the more numerous insertion sequences and contains 4 plasmids pINV-2457T, pSf2, and pSf4, and pSf-R27. Plasmid pINV-2457T is similar to plasmids pWR100, pWR501, and pCP301 whereas plasmid pSf-R27 is similar to R27. Plasmids pSf2 and pSf4 are small ColE1-like plasmids. pSf2 is similar to plasmid p2457TS2 found in RefSeq Accession Number NC_002773.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of chronic respiratory tract infections in chicken and other avian species.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma gallisepticum strain R. The strain has been extensively studied in regards of cyto-adherence and host invasion. Low passage number cultures are capable of invading cultured cells in ~20 minutes in model experiments, whereas high passage number cultures only attach to the host cells and lose the ability to invade them.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute and Duke University collaborated to sequence the Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii strain H99 (serotype A) genome at 11X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. They integrated the WGS sequences with BAC end sequences provided by Jim Kronstad and the Genome Sciences Centre to generate a Cryptococcus neoformans H99 genome assembly consisting of 341 contigs (>2 kb) placed into 210 scaffolds; the assembly excludes ribosomal RNA genes and very highly conserved repetitive sequence. The Cryptococcus neoformans H99 genome assembly is undergoing automated annotation.

bioproject.title: Budding bacterium of marine and freshwater environments.
bioproject.description: Rhodopirellula baltica SH 1. Rhodopirellula baltica SH 1 (DSM 10527) was isolated from the water column of Kieler Bucht (a fiord near the city of Kiel in Germany) and seems to be strongly involved in the first part of the degradation of complex macromolecules produced by autotrophic organisms like algae and cyanobacteria. This organism lacks a peptidoglycan layer, although it does contain genes and gene remnants for petidoglycan synthesis.

bioproject.organism: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1375
bioproject.title: Smallest and most abundant bacterium that has unique photosynthesizing components
bioproject.description: Prochlorococcus marinus subsp. marinus str. CCMP1375. This very low light-adapted strain is also known as strain SS120.

bioproject.title: Causes pharyngitis, bronchitis and pneumonitis
bioproject.description: Chlamydophila pneumoniae strain TW-183. This is the type strain for Chlamydophila pneumoniae. An ocular isolate first isolated in 1965 from a child's conjunctiva (the membranes lining the eyelid) during a trachoma vaccine trial in Taiwan. However, it naturally causes respiratory rather than ocular infections.

bioproject.title: Endospore- and mycelial-forming bacterium that infects cyst-forming nematodes
bioproject.description: Pasteuria nishizawae str. North American . Pasteuria nishizawae str. North American was isolated from nematode infested research plots. This organism has been used to further elucidate the life cycle of this nematode pathogen. Submitted sequence represents 0.5% of the genome.

bioproject.title: Primary endosymbiont of carpenter ants
bioproject.description: Candidatus Blochmannia floridanus. Candidatus Blochmannia floridanus, like similar endosymbionts, has lost many genes and maintains a minimal set for growth inside the host cell. Genes that have been retained include those for the production of metabolites useful to the host organim such as those for the production of a number of essential amino acids. In exchange for these services, the bacterium receives essential metabolites from the host in order to function. For example, the bacteria produce citrulline which the host uses to produce arginine which the bacteria then catabolizes. Candidatus Blochmannia floridanus also forms reduced sulfate for host cysteine production. Interestingly, similar traits are observed in mitochondria, including the fact that these bacteria appear to be maternally transmitted through oocytes to the ant progeny.

bioproject.title: Tropical and subtropical environmental organism which produces the bacteriocidal pigment violacein
bioproject.description: Chromobacterium violaceum ATCC 12472. Chromobacterium violaceum ATCC 12472 was isolated from freshwater in Malaya. This organism has a violacein operon for pigment production which is under quorum-sensing control, as are a number of important metabolic functions. This organism also has a chromosomally-encoded type III secretion system that is similar to systems from Salmonella and Yersinia, and may be important for the pathogenicity occasionally observed with this organism. The genome also contains genes for type I and type II secretion systems, various hemolysin-like sequences, and genes for pili production.

bioproject.title: Nonpathogenic bacterium isolated from rumen that contains numerous pathogenic genes
bioproject.description: Wolinella succinogenes strain DSM 1740. This organism was first isolated from the rumen of a cow and is considered nonpathogenic in both its host and in humans. However, this organism contains a number of virulence genes, including some found within genomic islands, which resemble genes from Campylobacter jejuni. These include a chromosomal type IV secretion system that resembles that found on the Campylobacter jejuni virulence plasmid pVir, and the Campylobacter jejuni secreted invasion antigen B (ciaB). The chromosome also contains nitrogen-fixation genes that may have been horizontally-transferred from bacteria within the Rhizobiaciae group.

bioproject.title: Obligate intracellular pathogen that causes North Asian tick typhus
bioproject.description: This is a reference strain from Krasnojarsk, Russia, 1949. Virulence factors include a type IV secretion system.

bioproject.title: Oral bacterium contributing to tooth decay.
bioproject.description: Fusobacterium nucleatum subsp. vincentii ATCC49256 . This strain is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Causes dental caries
bioproject.description: Streptococcus sobrinus strain 6715. This strain is able to induce caries in rat.

bioproject.title: Social gliding soil bacterium
bioproject.description: Myxococcus xanthus strain DK 1622. Myxococcus xanthus strain DK 1622 has a large genome (9.14Mb) containing more than 1500 gene duplication events. These gene duplications more commonly involve genes used in cell to cell signaling, molecule sensing and transcription control.

bioproject.title: Causes acute polyarthritis in rats and chronic proliferative arthritis in mice.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma arthritidis strain 158L3-1. This is a virulent strain which carries the lysogenic bacteriophage, MAV1, integrated into the chromosome.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that affects immunocompromised patients, especially those with liver damage
bioproject.description: Vibrio vulnificus strain YJ016. This is a Biotype 1 hospital isolate from Taiwan. It contains larger chromosomes and >1000 genes as compared to Vibrio cholerae and contains a conjugative plasmid, pYJ016. There are numerous virulence factors including a cytolysin, protease, capsular polysaccharide as well as iron-uptake systems encoded in the genome.

bioproject.title: Celera Genomics WGS human genome sequencing project
bioproject.description: Celera Genomics was founded to sequence and assemble the human genome and pioneered the use of whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing strategy for large eukaryotic genomes. A first draft sequence was completed in slightly over two years, sooner than expected and nearly a year ahead of their original goal.  Celera published a draft human genome assembly based on WGS sequence data and the BAC clone sequence data generated by the International Human Genome Consortium.

bioproject.title: Magnaporthe oryzae 70-15 RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly (see linked project PRJNA13840). Annotation on the RefSeq genomic records is propagated from the INSDC submission. RefSeq records may differ from the submitted annotation in format details, some protein names, and occasionally in feature location details.

bioproject.title: Takifugu rubripes Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description:
The fugu genome was determined by the International Fugu Genome Consortium using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing strategy. 
Fugu is the second vertebrate genome to be sequence and followed the release of the human genome sequence.

bioproject.title: 13x WGS sequencing and assembly by The Broad Institute
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute sequenced the Ciona savignyi genome at 13x coverage by whole genome shotgun (WGS) from a single individual with a high level of heterozygosity, estimated at 19%. Contigs and scaffolds were made from each separate haplotype, and the haplotype assemblies were compared to produce paired scaffold assemblies (PSAs). The assembly contains 164 Mb, which represents about 91% of the C. savignyi genome.

bioproject.title: Plasmodium yoelii yoelii strain:17XNL Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description:
The Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR) in collaboration with the Naval Medical Research Center carried out a research program to sequence the entire genome of the rodent malaria parasite Plasmodium yoelii yoelii. The genome sequencing of the malaria parasites P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. yoelii, P. berghei and P. chabaudi will provide a deeper insight into the evolutionary history of these species.

The Plasmodium yoelii yoelii whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession AABL00000000. The current version of the project (01) has the accession number AABL01000000, and consists of sequences AABL01000001-AABL01005687. Each accession contains the sequence of a single contig. Contigs larger than 2kb (20 Mb in total) have been annotated, representing approximately 87% of the total genome sequence. This annotation was generated in an automated fashion and should be considered preliminary and subject to revision.

bioproject.title: Whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing of the Anopheles gambiae genome
bioproject.description:
The PEST strain of Anopheles gambiae was selected for complete genome sequencing due to the prior existence of BAC libraries and physical maps. With these reagents already in hand, the initial whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequence was assembled with the Celera assembler. The A. gambiae Genome Project is now coordinated by the International Anopheles Genome Executive Committee (IAGEC), which is responsible for subsequent amendments to the sequence and for related database management and coordination in consultation with The Anopheles Genome International Executive Board (AGIEB).

The A. gambiae str. PEST whole genome shotgun (WGS) project has the project accession AAAB00000000. The current version of the project (01) has the accession number AAAB01000000, and consists of sequences AAAB01000001-AAAB01069724.

bioproject.title: Protozoan that is an intestinal parasite of humans and other mammals
bioproject.description:
The G. lamblia (ATCC 50803) strain WB, clone C6 genome was sequenced to 11.3 coverage using the whole genome shotgun method. It is 12 Mb in size and contains 6488 predicted open reading frames distributed throughout five chromosomes (chromosome polymorphism has been identified in different strains) and more than 13,100 predicted proteins. Karyotyping studies found chromosome sizes to range from 1.6 to over 3.8 Mb.

The newest G. lamblia assembly and annotation was released on GiardiaDB on April 17, 2007. This database as well as the G. lamblia genome project are managed by the Marine Biology Laboratories in Woods Hole and involves collaboration from University of Texas at El Paso, University of Arizona at Tucson, and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Funding is provided by NIAID.

This Whole Genome Shotgun sequencing project has been completed and deposited at DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank under the project accession AACB02000000.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by the Broad Institute as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute conducted a comparative genomic analysis of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces paradoxus. They produced a high-quality draft sequence of the Saccharomyces paradoxus strain NRRLY-17217 genome at 7.7X sequence coverage using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach. The assembly, which represents approximately 98% of the Saccharomyces paradoxus genome, consists of 832 contigs.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by the Broad Institute as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute conducted a comparative genomic analysis of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces bayanus. They produced a high-quality draft sequence of the Saccharomyces bayanus strain MCYC 623 genome at 6.4X sequence coverage using a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach. The assembly, which represents approximately 98% of the Saccharomyces bayanus genome, consists of 1,098 contigs. The WGS sequences have been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AACA00000000.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by WashU as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: WashU performed a comparative genomics study of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces kudriavzevii. They sequenced the Saccharomyces kudriavzevii strain IFO 1802 genome at 3.4X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Version 1 of the assembly, which totals approximately 10.6 Mb, consists of 2,007 contigs. Version 2 of the assembly consists of 2,029 contigs. The WGS sequences have been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AACI00000000.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by WashU as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: WashU performed a comparative genomics study of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces bayanus. They sequenced the Saccharomyces bayanus strain 623-6C genome at 2.9X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Version 1 of the assembly, which represents approximately 88% of the Saccharomyces bayanus genome, consists of 2,407 contigs. Version 2 of the assembly consists of 586 contigs; these contigs include traces submitted to the NCBI Trace Archive by the Broad Institute. The WGS sequences have been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AACG00000000.

bioproject.title: Genomic sequence determined by WashU as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: WashU conducted a comparative genomic analysis of several Saccharomyces species, including Saccharomyces castellii. They sequenced the Saccharomyces castellii strain NRRL Y-12630 genome at 3.9X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The assembly, which totals approximately 11.1 Mb, consists of 570 contigs. The WGS sequences have been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AACF00000000.

bioproject.title: Lachancea kluyveri NRRL Y-12651 WGS sequencing
bioproject.description: WashU conducted a comparative genomic analysis of several ascomycete yeast species, including Lachancea kluyveri (synonym: Saccharomyces kluyveri). They sequenced the Lachancea kluyveri strain NRRL Y-12651 genome using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Version 1 of the assembly, which represents 3.6X sequence coverage and approximately 81% of the Lachancea kluyveri genome, consists of 2,381 contigs. Version 2 of the assembly consists of 1,275 contigs. Version 3 of the assembly, which represents 10.2X sequence coverage, consists of 34 contigs.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing, assembly, and annotation
bioproject.description:
The Broad Institute sequenced the Ustilago maydis strain 521 genome at 10X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Version 1 of the genome assembly consists of 274 nuclear genome contigs in 47 scaffolds, and 2 mitochondrial genome contigs; it excludes ribosomal RNA genes and very highly conserved repetitive sequence. The genome assembly was annotated using automated gene prediction tools, and the predicted gene models were manually refined.

To validate their genome assembly and to anchor the scaffolds to chromosomes, the Broad Institute aligned their WGS assembly to the strain 521 clone-based assembly provided by Bayer CropScience. The Broad Institute also aligned their strain 521 WGS assembly to the Ustilago maydis strain FB1 assembly to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms between these two strains.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing by the Broad Institute
bioproject.description: The Broad Institute sequenced the Coprinopsis cinerea strain okayama7#130 genome at 10X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The current assembly, which represents approximately 96% of the Coprinopsis cinerea genome, contains 106 supercontigs from 431 contigs longer than 2 kb.

bioproject.title: Citrus sinensis
bioproject.description: Currently many independent groups are involved in the generation of ESTs from C. sinensis. Citrus HarvEST database developed at the University of California, Riverside, maintains citrus EST data. Citrus HarvEST is supported by funds from California Citrus Research Board and University of California Discovery Grant Program.

bioproject.title: Economically important, red marine algae
bioproject.description:
Porphyra is a blade-forming red seaweed that appear on rocky shorelines throughout the world. It is one or two cells in thickness and ranges from a few mm to over 3 m in length. The blades vary in color from yellow, olive, pink, to even purple. It has a unique dimorphic life cycle consisting of two generations, a leafy, haploid gametophyte and a microscopic diploid filamentous sporophyte. Porphyras are extremely dessication-tolerant, a focus of intense physiological research. Certain species are edible, used as wrapping around sushi rolls.

Porphyra yezoensis is an economically significant species because of its use in sushi making. It has a small genome of about 260 Mb and can undergo, in a laboratory system, a complete life cycle within a few months. It has therefore been recognized as a model plant for studying fundamental and applied processes in marine biological sciences.

bioproject.title: Coccolithophorid alga with world-wide distribution.
bioproject.description:
The haptophyte Emiliania huxleyi is the dominant coccolithophorid forming mesoscale blooms across diverse regimes in the contemporary oceans, often in regions inhospitable to other phytoplankton. Through its ability to both calcify and photosynthetically fix carbon, this group of small calcite-covered microalgae exerts profound control over global climate by mediating the exchange of CO2 between the atmosphere and the ocean and has done so for hundreds of thousands of years. This first sequenced haptophyte genome fills the gap in the eukaryotic tree of life. Genome sequence analysis will provide insights into key steps in the biomineralization of calcite, light harvesting, acquiring nutrients and metabolism.

E. huxleyi has a genome size of about 220 Mb

bioproject.title: Photosynthetic algal species with a number of orange-brown chloroplasts.
bioproject.description: Alexandrium tamarense is a photosynthetic dinoflagellate found in coastal and estuarine regions of the world. The genome size is approximately ca. 200 pg/cell with about 143 or 144 chromosomes of unknown sizes (Courtesy Dr. Debashish Bhattacharya, University of Iowa). Though mainly present in cold to cold-temperate waters, it has also been reported in warmer waters. It is haploid except for the sexual stage. Some strains produce potent neurotoxins such as gonyautoxins and saxitoxin that can affect humans and other mammals, fish, and birds. It is being used as a model organism to study the evolution of capture of photosynthetic organelles through endosymbiosis.

bioproject.title: Small flowering plant of mustard family and the first to be completely sequenced
bioproject.description:
Arabidopsis thaliana is a small flowering plant of mustard family, brassicaceae (Cruciferae). It is distributed throughout the world and was first reported in the sixteenth century by Johannes Thal. It has been used for over fifty years to study plant mutations and for classical genetic analysis. It is now being used as a model organism to study different aspects of plant biology.

A. thaliana is a diploid plant with 2n = 10 chromosomes. It became the first plant genome to be fully sequenced based on the fact that it has a (1) small genome of ~120 Mb with a simple structure having few repeated sequences (2) short generation time of six weeks from seed germination to seed set, and (3) produces large number of seeds. The sequencing was done by an international collaboration collectively termed the Arabidopsis Genome Initiative (AGI). Though of no economic importance, it is an invaluable resource to agriculturally important crops, particularly to members of the same family, which includes canola, an important source of vegetable oil.

bioproject.title: Glycine max Organism overview
bioproject.description:
Glycine max, is an annual herb of great economic importance. It belongs to family Fabaceae and tribe Phaseoleae which includes several other important legumes like beans, pigeon pea, black gram, mung bean etc. It is believed to have originated in Asia but is now cultivated extensively for food and forage throughout the world. It is a major source of vegetable oil and protein in the world. Each soybean seed contains about 20% oil and about 50% of the remaining meal is protein.

The genome of G. max is a diploidized tetraploid with 2n = 40 chromosomes and a genome size of about 1115 Mb. Several well developed genomic resources are available: a well developed composite genetic map, large number of ESTs and a number of BAC libraries. The soybean genome sequence was deposited in NCBI in 2010 as WGS scaffolds and chromosome pseudomolecules. In 2011 the RefSeq chromosome accessions were prepared by NCBI.

bioproject.title: Medicago truncatula Organism overview
bioproject.description: Medicago truncatula is a forage legume with a small genome size (~500 Mbp). Legumes are important source of proteins containing from 20 to 50 percent protein on a dry weight basis. As a legume, M. truncatula establishes symbiotic relationships with nitrogen fixing Rhizobia. Roots of M. truncatula are also colonized by beneficial arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi. Among legumes it is considered an outstanding model for genome research as it has a diploid genome, simple genetics, and short generation time. There is high conservation between the genome of M. truncatula and the genomes of alfalfa and pea. There is moderate conservation between the genome of M. truncatula and the genome of soybean. This leads to the idea that M. truncatula can be a nodal species for comparative and functional genomics of legumes. The genome sequence of M. truncatula was deposited in NCBI in mid 2011 as chromosome pseudomolecules. The RefSeq records were prepared in late 2011.

bioproject.title: Solanum lycopersicum Organism overview
bioproject.description: Solanum lycopersicum has been used for a number of firsts in molecular genetics of plants. The use of RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphism) to generate a linkage map of a complete plant genome was done with tomato (Bernatzky and Tanksley. Genetics 1986; 112:887-898). Tomato was the organism where quantitative traits were resolved into Mendelian factors (Paterson et al.). The use of allelic variation of RAPD (random amplification of polymorphic DNA) to facilitate map-based walking to agronomically pertinent loci was first done in tomato (Wing et al. and Martin et al.). The creation of a high-density molecular linkage map and the use for comparative genomics were done with tomato and potato (Tanksley et al.). In February 2011 the chromosome pseudomolecules were deposited in NCBI.

bioproject.title: Avena sativa Organism overview
bioproject.description:
Any effort to determine the nucleotide sequence of the cultivated oat genome suffers from three impediments. First, the genome size of cultivated oat is approximately 16000 Mbp. This is more than five times larger than human, with the associated technical difficulties encountered during the Human Genome Initiative. Second, cultivated oat is an allopolyploid of three component genomes - a hexaploid. This fact only partially accounts for the size difference between oat and human. Third, financial support for such an effort, with the obligatory prior development of reagents and a knowledge-base, is directly related to agronomic importance, whether measured in acres under cultivation, bushels produced annually, or pecuniary value of that produced. By any of these criteria, oat in the United States is far behind the other grasses - wheat, barley, corn, and rice.

The reduced financial support noted above has been a long-standing feature of cultivated oat research with the consequence of being an impediment to producing genetic maps. The other impediment is a collection of technical conditions. First, in the hexaploid strains translocations between the chromosomes of the component genomes disrupt the ability to presume homosequential gene order among the genomes or between the diploid strains to the hexaploid genomes. Second, only recently has a complete aneuploid series been developed. This reagent enables overcoming the limited ability to discrimate chromosomes on the basis of morphology and has allowed the assignment of the homoeologous groupings. Reducing the barrier imposed by the technical impediments has been the elucidation of "anchor probes", DNA probes for loci that are common to a number of the agronomically important grasses (VanDeynze et al. Theor Appl Genet 1998; 97: 356-369).

bioproject.title: Hordeum vulgare Organism overview
bioproject.description: Barley is an economically important cereal crop, along with wheat and rye. It belongs to the family Gramineae, tribe Triticieae. Barley is the most widely cultivated diploid member of this tribe, making it a good model for this entire group of plants. Obtaining barley sequence will be useful as it contains genes for agronomically desirable traits like stress, pest and disease resistance. At the same time, sequence analysis will help improve the feed quality. Since the genome of members of Triticeae are large (about 5000 Mb for barley), barley researchers have put their efforts into developing a physical map of barley and creating large number of ESTs which are used to identify loci in a genetic map. The North American Barley Genome project is a multi-institutional, multidisciplinary project that is involved in locating and characterizing genes of economic importance and to use these genes in applied plant breeding. A number of groups have begun collecting sequence from different cultivars.

bioproject.title: Oryza sativa Organism overview
bioproject.description:
Rice is one of the most important food crops in the world and feeds more people than any other crop. Rice belongs to the genus Oryza which includes approximately 24 species. They are widely distributed growing in different habitats and different soil types. They show differences in plant growth, yield, pest and disease resistance, stress tolerance and water requirenment. Rice grain is classified as short, medium or long grain sizes and and exhibits colors like brown, black, purple, and red.
