It is an important model system for studying the evolution of vertebrate development and the origin of vertebrate genomes.

bioproject.title: Pheromones were initially identified in silkworms, which are now studied for silk quality improvement
bioproject.description:
The silkworm Bombyx mori has been domesticated for silk production for about 5,000 years and intensively studied. As a result, knowledge of its biology and genetics is the most advanced of any lepidopteran species. Comparison with its wild ancestor B. mandarina provides the opportunity to examine the effects of artificial selection leading to domestication at the genome level.

Lepidoptera genomes are unusual in that they have holocentric chromosomes with diffuse kinetochores; as a result, they are able to retain chromosome fragments through many cell divisions. Silkworm is a female-heterogametic species with a ZW chromosome combination specifying female, and ZZ male.

Interactions between Lepidoptera and baculoviruses have led to important biotechnological advances in recombinant protein production, and point toward enhancing the efficacy of these environmentally benign biological control agents. Other viruses (polydnaviruses) are able to modulate the lepidopteran endocrine and immune systems, and are vectored by hymenopteran parasites used in biological control.

bioproject.title: Extremely virulent organism that causes plague
bioproject.description: Yersinia pestis biovar Microtus str. 91001. Formerly the Medievalis subtype (biovar) that is widely used in research and is well characterized. The biovar has been renamed to Microtus.
bioproject.organization: Academy of Military Medical Sciences, The Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology, China

bioproject.title: Causative agent of enzootic pneumonia in swine.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae strain 7448. This pathogenic strain was isolated from an infected pig in Lindoia do Sul, Santa Catarina, in Brazil.
bioproject.organization: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica

bioproject.title: Thermoacidophilic organism that grows at extremes of temperature and pH
bioproject.description: Picrophilus torridus strain DSM 9790. The genome sequence of this strain will allow investigation of the evolution of organisms sharing the extreme growth conditions of a unique niche.
bioproject.organization: Institut of Microbiology and Genetics, University of Goettingen

bioproject.title: Nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria that also produce a variety of cyanotoxins
bioproject.description: Anabaena variabilis ATCC 29413. This is a wild-type strain which differs from the closely related Anabaena sp. PCC7120 in the heterocyst formation system in that this strain does not have a programmed gene rearrangement at the hupL locus.

bioproject.title: Freshwater cyanobacteria that is extensively studied due to circadian rhythms.
bioproject.description: Synechococcus elongatus strain PCC 7942. This was the first strain to be reliably transformed by exogenous DNA and is closely related to the type strain of Synechococcus elongatus, PCC 6301. This strain is a freshwater organism and is extensively studied due to its circadian clock which controls the expression of upwards of 800 genes during a 24 hour period. This organism contains 2 plasmids as well.

bioproject.title: Model organism for hydrogen oxidation and used for bioremediation of aromatic compounds
bioproject.description: Ralstonia eutropha strain JMP134. This organism is found in both soil and water and has great potential for use in bioremediation as it is capable of degrading a large list of pollutants including chlorinated aromatic compounds. The bacterium can utilize hydrogen, carbon dioxide, as well as organic compounds for growth and is a model organism for hydrogen oxidation as it can grow on hydrogen as the sole energy source. It was originally isolated due to its ability to degrade the herbicide 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid, which is due to the degradative functions being encoded on a plasmid (pJP4).

bioproject.title: Fast-growing methylotrophic bacterium
bioproject.description: Methylobacillus flagellatus strain KT. This organism contains multiple formaldehyde degradation pathways including a ribulose monophosphate (RMP) cycle and a linear pathway utilizing tetrahydromethanopterin-dependent enzymes. Degradation of formaldehydge is part of the process of incorporating carbon into the cell, and as this organism is an obligate methylotroph and can only utilize methanol and methylamine as the sole carbon and energy sources, conversion of intermediates is both an important part of the growth of cell and an exploitable process for industrial purposes. This strain was isolated from activated sludge found at the wastewater treatment plant in Moscow, Russia and is the fastest growing methylotroph discovered. The fast growth and conversion rate make it useful in industrial production of biomolecules.

bioproject.title: Endospore forming thermophilic acetogen
bioproject.description: Moorella thermoacetica ATCC 39073. This organism will be used for comparative analysis with other acetogenic bacteria.

bioproject.title: Can survive after long term exposure to cold
bioproject.description: Exiguobacterium sibiricum 255-15. This organism was isolated from a 2-3 million-year permafrost core in Siberia, Russia and can survive and grow rapidly at low temperatures. Analysis of long-term survival of psychrophilic organisms such as this one may aid understanding of the potential growth of organisms in astrobiology.

bioproject.title: Non-pathogenic mycoplasma to be used for minimal genome studies
bioproject.description: Mesoplasma florum strain L1. Mesoplasma florum strain L1, (ATCC 33453) formerly Acholeplasma florum, was isolated from the surface of the lemon tree flower. This is the type strain and will be used for comparative analysis with the pathogenic Mycoplasma species.

bioproject.title: Marine nitrogen-fixing bacterium
bioproject.description: Crocosphaera watsonii WH 8501. Crocosphaera watsonii WH 8501, formerly Synechocystis sp. WH 8501, was isolated from the tropical southern Atlantic Ocean. This organism is able to efficiently transport phosphorus which may play an important role in its ability to survive in the oligotrophic tropical ocean.

bioproject.title: ladyfish RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Elops saurus, or ladyfish, is a gamefish that is found in the western Atlantic Ocean. This coastal fish travels in schools.

The Elops saurus mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between it and a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Tarpon RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Megalops atlanticus, or tarpon, are primarily found in coastal waters on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. This fish is a gamefish in America and the commercial sale of tarpon is prohibited.

The Megalops atlanticus mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Axolotl RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome for Ambystoma mexicanum has been sequenced and published.

bioproject.title: Hawaiian ladyfish RefSeq mitochondrial genome.
bioproject.description:
Elops hawaiensis, or Hawaiian ladyfish, is a gamefish that is found in the western central Pacific. This coastal fish travels in schools.

The Elops hawaiensis mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: pelican eel RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Gulper eel. These well-known deep-sea creatures exist at bathypelagic depths (>1,000 m) throughout the world's oceans. They are characterized by an enlarged mouth and eel-like body with a luminous organ at the end of their tails. Crustaceans are a major food source for these animals.

The Eurypharynx pelecanoides mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Long-clawed shrew RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The Tokyo Institute of Technology sequenced the mitochondrial genome of the Sorex unguiculatus (long-clawed shrew) to study phylogeny.

bioproject.title: Redbanded seabream RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome of Pagrus auriga, the redbanded seabream, has been sequenced.

bioproject.title: Indo-Pacific tarpon RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Megalops cyprinoides, or Indo-Pacific tarpon, are primarily found in coastal waters of the Pacific Ocean. This is a popular gamefish, with adults generally found at sea, but with the young found more coastal and also in freshwater.

The Megalops cyprinoides mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between it and a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Kaup's arrowtooth eel RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Synaphobranchus kaupii, or Kaup's Arrowtooth eel, is a deep-sea eel, living in depths from 200-4800 meters in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans.

The Synaphobranchus kaupii mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Ophisurus macrorhynchos, is also known as a snake eel. These ocean-dwelling creatures are carnivorous.

The Ophisurus macrorhynchos mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between it and a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Japanese gissu RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Pterothrissus gissu, or Japanese gissu, is a deepwater bonefish found in the Northwest Pacific Ocean.

The Pterothrissus gissu mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between it and a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Roundjaw bonefish RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Albula glossodonta, is a saltwater bonefish that is usually used as a baitfish. They live in shallow regions and feed on shrimp, mollusks and small crabs.

The Albula glossodonta mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species to identify the evolutionary origin of the leptocephalus larva.

bioproject.title: Gilbert's halosaur RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Aldrovandia affinis, also known as Gilbert's halosaur, is a deep-sea eel.

The Aldrovandia affinis mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Rhinolophus pumilus
bioproject.organization: Tokyo Institute of Technology, Graduate School of Bioscience and Biotechnology; Midori-ku Nagatuta-cho 4259, Yokohama, Kanagawa 2268501, Japan

bioproject.title: Thermophilic bacterium capable of degrading hemicellulose and xylan.
bioproject.description: Rubrobacter xylanophilus strain DSM 9941. This is the type strain of the species and is used for comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Sea firefly RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome of Vargula hilgendorfii has been sequenced by National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology. The genome contains the same 37 genes, compared to other Arthropoda, but the gene order varies.

bioproject.title: Huso huso
bioproject.organization: University College London, Department of Biology

bioproject.title: Lavenberg's gulper-eel RefSeq mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description:
Saccopharynx lavenbergi, is collectively described as a Gulper eel. These deep-sea creatures exist at bathypelagic depths (2-3,000 m) in the Eastern Central Pacific ocean. They are characterized by an enlarged mouth and eel-like body.

The Saccopharynx lavenbergi mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the University of Tokyo to study the phylogenetic relationships between a number of different fish species.

bioproject.title: Causative agent of enzootic pneumonia in swine.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae strain J. This strain (J; ATCC 25934) was isolated from an agricultural sample. It is nonpathogenic and exhibits decreased adhesion capacity to porcine cilia.
bioproject.organization: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica

bioproject.title: Causative agent of respiratory tract infections in chicken.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma synoviae 53. This strain was isolated from a broiler breeder in the state of Parana in Brazil.
bioproject.organization: LNCC - Laboratorio Nacional de Computacao Cientifica

bioproject.title: Rhinolophus monoceros
bioproject.organization: Institute of Molecular Biosciences, New Zealand

bioproject.title: Obligate intracellular pathogen that causes endemic typhus
bioproject.description: Rickettsia typhi strain Wilmington. This is a commonly used strain.
bioproject.organization: Human Genome Sequencing Center, Baylor College of Medicine

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequence by Whitney Laboratory, University of Florida
bioproject.organization: Whitney Laboratory, University of Florida, Neuroscience, USA

bioproject.title: mitochondrial genome of the Chilean shrew opossum
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly. Annotation provided on the RefSeq genomic records is based on NCBI annotation pipeline.

bioproject.title: Dromiciops gliroides
bioproject.organization: Nilsson M.A., Dept. of Cell and Organism Biology, University of Lund, Solvegatan 29, S-22362 Lund, SWEDEN

bioproject.title: Caenolestes fuliginosus
bioproject.organization: Nilsson M.A., Dept. of Cell and Organism Biology, University of Lund, Solvegatan 29, S-22362 Lund, SWEDEN

bioproject.organism: Leptospira interrogans serovar Copenhageni str. Fiocruz L1-130
bioproject.title: Causes leptospirosis
bioproject.description: Leptospira interrogans serovar copenhageni strain Fiocruz L1-130. This strain was isolated from a patient with severe leptospirosis during an epidemic in 1996.

bioproject.title: Radiotolerant bacterium isolated from a radioactive waste basin.
bioproject.description: Kineococcus radiotolerans SRS30216. This organism is a coccoid bacterium originally isolated from a high-level radioactive waste cell at the Savannah River Site in Aiken, South Carolina, USA, in 2002. This is the type strain of the species. Comparative functional genomic characterization of this species and other known radiotolerant bacteria such as Deinococcus radiodurans and Rubrobacter xylanophilus will shed light onto the strategies these bacteria use for survival in high radiation environments, as well as the evolutionary origins of radioresistance and their highly efficient DNA repair machinery.

bioproject.title: Bacterium capable of EDTA degradation
bioproject.description: Mesorhizobium sp. BNC1. This organism was isolated from a mixed-culture enriched from sewage using the chelating agent EDTA (binds divalent cations - ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid) as the sole carbon and nitrogen source. EDTA is often found at toxic waste sites where it is bound to metals and radionuclides, which affects bioremediation efforts. This bacterium is capable of EDTA degradation by itself.

bioproject.title: The mitochondrial genome of Drosophila simulans was sequenced from isolate TT00
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome of Drosophila simulans was sequenced from isolate TT00, originating in Tahiti, French Polynesia. Sequencing the mtDNA from several species of Drosophila allows for comparative genomics studies that can reveal evolutionary changes and the mechanisms that cause them.
bioproject.organization: The Field Museum, Department of Zoology, USA

bioproject.title: Gibberella zeae
bioproject.description:
The genetic map of Gibberella zeae lineage 7 was constructed using a cross between the type strain PH-1 (NRRL 31084) and a strain from Minnesota, 00-676 (NRRL 34097). Cytological examination of parental strains indicated that each have four chromosomes. A total of 112 random ascospore progeny were analyzed for 122 genetic loci; 110 of the markers exhibited Mendelian inheritance.

Genetic markers consist of single nucleotide polymorphisms (n=66), RFLPs (n= 29), and microsatellites (n=27). Most SNPs and RFLPs were identified by sequencing alleles derived from EST loci for both parental strains; others were based on sequences at the ends of smaller scaffolds. One EST-based marker (HK235) and a marker based on the major ribosomal RNA repeat were not represented in the assembly but both map to linkage group 9 on chromosome 4. Microsatellites were obtained from a genome-wide scan for simple tandem repeats by the method of Benson (Nucleic Acids Res. 27:573-580, 1999) and then used for polymorphism screening at selected loci.

bioproject.title: Causes tick-born disease canine ehrlichiosis
bioproject.description: Ehrlichia canis strain Jake. This strain was isolated in 1989 in North Carolina from a 2-year-old male dog.

bioproject.title: Causes necrotizing pneumonia, chronic infections
bioproject.description: Burkholderia sp. 383. This strain will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Bioremediation and biocontrol bacterium
bioproject.description: Burkholderia vietnamiensis G4. This strain is a proficient degrader of trichloroethylene, benzene, and tolulene and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Fast gliding mycoplasma isolated from fish.
bioproject.description: Mycoplasma mobile Strain 163K. Mycoplasma mobile Strain 163K (ATCC 43663) is the only known strain of the species. It is not pathogenic for humans or animals. However, this organism was originally isolated (1984) from the gills of a fresh-water fish, the tench. It is the first mycoplasmal isolate that colonizes an aquatic organism. The unusual habitat explains lower temperature growth optimum of 20 degrees Celsius. M. mobile can glide at speeds of up to 7 microns/sec, much faster that any other known gliding mycoplasmas. Investigation of the fast gliding motility phenomenon was a primary driver for sequencing this genome.

bioproject.title: Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans JEC21 RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly (see linked project PRJNA13856). Annotation on the RefSeq genomic records is propagated from the INSDC submission. RefSeq records may differ from the submitted annotation in format details, some protein names, and occasionally in feature location details.

bioproject.title: Probable pneumonia agent
bioproject.description: Candidatus Protochlamydia amoebophila UWE25. An endosymbiont of free-living amoebae (Acanthamoeba sp. endosymbiont UWE25) and implicated as a potential human pathogen this strain is an environmental isolate. Its genome size is approximately twice as large as other pathogenic species belonging to the Chlamydiaceae family.

bioproject.title: WGS sequencing, assembly and annotation
bioproject.description: The current reference assembly of Candida albicans SC5314 is haplotype A of assembly 22 updated by Candida Genome Database of Stanford University. The history of Candida albicans SC5314 genome sequencing is as follows: Stanford University sequenced the heterozygous diploid genome of Candida albicans strain SC5314 using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. They initially assembled the sequence using PHRAP, which resulted in an assembly (Assembly 6) in which the sum of the contigs significantly exceeded the haploid genome size due to the heterozygosity. They then developed computational methods to reconstruct the diploid genome sequence from the PHRAP assembly, which resulted in an assembly (Assembly 19) that was in good agreement with available physical mapping data.

bioproject.title: Coffea arabica is the oldest and most cultivated species of coffee plant.
bioproject.description:
Coffee, one of the world's largest traded commodities, comes from evergreen coffee trees. Coffea arabica is the earliest cultivated species of coffee and is still most widely grown. It is an allotetraploid with 11 sets of chromosomes (2n=4x=44). Linkage map has been developed for diploid species, C. canephora an economically important progenitor species of C. arabica. Large scale sequencing efforts are in progress in coffee with the aim of getting high yielding and better quality coffee varieties that are disease resistant and withstand harsh weather conditions.
A database of Coffee genomics, CoffeeDNA, has been developed by Genomics group in University of Trieste, Italy, that maintains and provides coffee genomics data to the scientific community.
Brazilian Consortium on Coffee Research and Development and a network of 20 laboratories coordinated by the State of Sao Paulo Research Foundation (Fapesp) have finished sequencing the Coffee genome. Sequence has not been made public as yet.

bioproject.title: domestic cat
bioproject.description:
Felis catus, the domestic cat, provides several valuable models for infectious disease, including a model for human AIDS. With a large number of recognized breeds, the cat is also a valuable resource for studying phenotypic diversity and evolution. The cat genome will further facilitate research in human medicine as some rare diseases that occur in humans also occur in this popular pet.

The Felis catus diploid genome is organized in 18 pairs of autosomes and two sex chromosomes.

bioproject.title: ultrasmall unicellular red alga
bioproject.description: Cyanidioschyzon merolae is a primitive, unicellular red alga with a compact genome and a simple gene composition. It lives in sulphate-rich, acidic hot waters. The cell contains a single nucleus, a single mitochondrion and a single chloroplast. The genome size is about 16 Mbp, smallest of all photosynthetic eukaryotes. The majority of genes do not include introns and smaller copy numbers are found for typically high-copy number genes such as ribosomal genes. Because of the simple gene composition, C. merolae genome provides a model system for studying the origin, evolution and fundamental mechanisms of eukaryotic cells.

bioproject.title: Western clawed frog  (Xenopus (Silurana) tropicalis) is an important model organism for studies in cell and developmental biology.
bioproject.description: The Western clawed frog, Xenopus (Silurana) tropicalis, is native to Africa and is an important model organism for the study of developmental genetics and vertebrate biology. In contrast to the African clawed frog (Xenopus laevis) which has a tetraploid genome and was used in the early years of embryological research, the Western clawed frog has a diploid genome which simplifies genetic studies.

bioproject.title: African clawed frog (Xenopus laevis) is an important model organism for cell and developmental biology.
bioproject.description: The tetraploid Xenopus laevis is native to Africa. X. laevis used to study vertebrate biology and early embryonic development and as a model for biomedical research. Xenopus studies have been instrumental in the elucidation of biochemical processes such as intracellular signaling, cytoskeletal assembly, and chromosome replication. Xenopus eggs are also commonly used in embryological studies.

bioproject.title: cow
bioproject.description: Bos taurus (cow) is an agriculturally important animal; beef and milk production are the largest manufacturing industries in the United States. The cow is an important model organism for health research in obesity, female health, and infectious diseases. Cow is also used in studies of endocrinology, physiology and reproductive techniques. The cow genome will be useful for comparative genomics, representing a non-primate, non-rodent eutherian genome. The B. taurus genome is estimated to be 3000 MB, organized in 29 pairs of autosomes and two sex chromosomes. Bovine chromosomes are acrocentric.

bioproject.title: sheep
bioproject.description:
Ovis aries, the domestic sheep, is an important livestock animal. It is a wool producing animal that has economic importance throughout the world. The genome sequence will facilitate the identification of genes that may provide explanations for the vast range of mammalian variation and help us to better understand the genetic basis of diseases common to both human and sheep.

The Ovis aries genome is distributed over 26 autosomes and two sex chromosomes.

bioproject.title: pig
bioproject.description:
The pig (Sus scrofa) is a member of the artiodactyls, or cloven-hoofed mammals, which are an evolutionary clade distinct from the primates and rodents. Pigs exist in both feral and domesticated populations that have distinct phenotypes and karyotypes. The haploid genome of the domesticated pig is estimated to be 2800 Mb. The diploid genome is organized in 18 pairs of autosomes and two sex chromosomes.

Sus scrofa is an important model organism for health research due to parallels with humans. Swine are omnivores and their digestive physiology is similar to humans. Similarities between humans and pigs also exist in renal function, vascular structure, and respiratory rates. Pigs are used as model organism in many areas of medical research including obesity, cardiovascular disease, endocrinology, alcoholism, diabetes, nephropathy, and organ transplantation. Pigs are also agriculturally important, as pork is a leading source of protein worldwide.

bioproject.title: Arabidopsis assembly project
bioproject.description:
Arabidopsis annotation was initially done by members of AGI (Arabidopsis Genome Initiative) which was later continued by the Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR) in collaboration with MIPS. After the final release of the annotated genome by TIGR in 2004, The Arabidopsis Information Resource (TAIR) assumed the responsibility of updating the Arabidopsis annotation. Annotation at TAIR is done by manual curation from the research literature and direct submissions from the research community. Detailed description of the annotation process is described by Swarbreck et al. in Nucleic Acids Res. 2008 January.

This assembly was created by NCBI based on the information provided by TAIR.

bioproject.title: cDNA sequencing projects from RIKEN and  SSP consortium
bioproject.description:
Full length cDNAs are essential to understand the function of genes. A. thaliana genome sequencing has revealed the presence of approximately 25,000 genes. In order to understand the transcriptional product of these genes, the SSP Consortium, originally SPP, consisting of Salk, Stanford, and PGEC, UC Berkley, is involved in isolation and complete sequencing of full-length cDNAs for 8000 genes. This project is funded by NSF Plant Genome Research Grant DBI9975718/0196098

A cDNA sequencing project is also in progress at the RIKEN Genomic Sciences Center, Japan, for functional analysis of Arabidopsis genes. They have constructed 20 full-length cDNA libraries using biotinylated CAP trapper method. Aim is to study genes induced during drought, cold and high salinity stress. They plan to collaborate with SSP consortium. Data generated by the SSP consortium and RIKEN has been submited to GenBank.

bioproject.title: Kazusa EST project
bioproject.description: Kazusa DNA Research Institute has been involved in generating large scale ESTs from Arabidopsis. EST sequences are deposited in Genbank and are also available through the Kazusa web site.

bioproject.title: A genome sequencing project from the Leishmania major Friedlin consortium.
bioproject.description:
The Leishmania major Friedlin consortium consists of The European Leishmania major Friedlin Genome Sequencing Consortium (EULEISH), the Seattle Biomedical Research Institute (SBRI), and The Sanger Institute. Individual chromosomes have been isolated using pulsed field gel electrophoresis and were sequenced using a cosmid clone methodology in conjunction with a chromosomal shotgun method.

Sequencing of all 36 chromosomes has been completed and gap closure is almost finalized. The genome is currently being annotated and thus far 8,272 genes have been identified in the ~33 Mb haploid genome. All L. major strain Friedlin sequence data is available in GenBank and in RefSeq.

bioproject.title: Genetic linkage map by U.S. Meat Animal Research Center
bioproject.description: The U.S. Meat Animal Research Center (MARC) has constructed a genetic linkage map for Sus scrofa. The swine mapping population consisted of eight litters resulting from mating two white composite crossbred boars mated to eight Chinese (Meishan Minzhu or Fengjing) or Duroc x white composite crossbred sows. Two sires, eight dams and 94 progeny were genotyped. No grandparents were genotyped. The map includes 1266 markers; total map distance is 2480 cM. The map data have been obtained from MARC, the Meat Animal Research Center (Rohrer et al. Genome Res 6(5):371-91,1996).

bioproject.title: dog
bioproject.description: The dog, Canis lupus familiaris, is a useful model organism for medical research due to extensive genetic diversity and morphological variation within the species and to aggressive breeding practices that have resulted in inbred populations of dogs. Many breeds of dog are particularly susceptible to inherited diseases that are also common in humans, such as cancer, heart disease, rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune disorders, deafness, and blindness. The size of the haploid dog genome is estimated to be 2445 Mb. The diploid genome is organized in 38 pairs of autosomes and two sex chromosomes.

bioproject.title: Radiation hybrid map from the University of Rennes
bioproject.description: A comprehensive radiation hybrid (RH) map of the dog genome was constructed at the University of Rennes, France using the RHDF5000-2 whole-genome radiation hybrid panel and computed using the MULTIMAP and TSP/CONCORDE programs. The 3270 markers map to 3021 unique positions and define an average inter-marker distance corresponding to 1 Mb.

bioproject.title: purple sea urchin; marine invertebrate used as a model organism to study embryological development and gene regulation
bioproject.description:
Echinoids are invertebrate marine animals that are found throughout the world. The group includes sea urchins and sand dollars. Echinoids exhibit pentaradial symmetry and have a skeleton, or test, of fused calcitic plates embedded in the skin. Tube-feet are used for feeding and respiration, and spines are involved in locomotion and defense against predators.

Echinoids are useful in evolutionary studies, as they are non-chordate deuterostomes. They are more closely related to humans and other chordates than flies or nematodes, and regions of synteny between sea urchins and mammals have been identified. Sea urchins have been used extensively for studies of gene regulation during development and other aspects of embryology. Sea urchins also exhibit a wide range of genetic variation, both between species and within a species.

bioproject.title: Brugia malayi genome sequencing project
bioproject.description:
Brugia malayi has a diploid genome of approximately 110 Mb, organized in 6 pairs of chromosomes (five pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes). In addition to the nuclear genome, B. malayi has a mitochondrial genome of about 14kb, and the genome of the harbored bacterial endosymbiont Wolbachia sp (1-2Mb).

The B. malayi genome project has been completed by The Institute for Genomic Research. Whole Genome Shotgun sequencing was used to obtain more than eight-fold coverage of the genome. The complete genome was assembled into approximately 8200 scaffolds and deposited in GenBank. The accession for the WGS project is AAQA00000000 and consists of sequences AAQA01000001-AAQA01029808.

bioproject.title: The genome of the Caenorhabditis briggsae was sequenced at the Sanger Institute
bioproject.description: The Sanger Institute has sequenced over 13 Mb of the Caenorhabditis briggsae genome, with over 1,000,000,000 whole genome shotgun reads from plasmids, bacterial artificial chromosomes, and fosmid ends.

bioproject.title: Related to Saccharomyces cerevisiae but diverged before a whole genome duplication event from which Baker's yeast arose
bioproject.description:
Lachancea waltii (synonym: Kluyveromyces waltii) is a yeast that shares a common ancestor with Saccharomyces cerevisiae but diverged before a ancient whole genome duplication from which Saccharomyces cerevisiae arose. This organism is not commonly used in the laboratory and is relatively uncharacterized.

The Lachancea waltii genome is approximately 11 Mb, organized in 8 chromosomes.

bioproject.title: Yeast sequenced by the Broad Institute as part of a comparative genomics study
bioproject.description: As part of a comparative genomics study designed to understand the mechanism of Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome evolution, the Broad Institute sequenced the Lachancea waltii (synonym: Kluyveromyces waltii) strain NCYC 2644 genome at 8X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. They assembled the Lachancea waltii sequence into essentially eight complete chromosomes, and annotated the draft genome, identifying 5,230 predicted protein-coding genes. The scientists concluded that Saccharomyces cerevisiae originated from an ancient whole-genome duplication.

bioproject.title: A dimorphic ascomycete causing coccidioidomycosis and morphologically indistinguishable from Coccidioides immitis.
bioproject.description: Although morphologically identical to Coccidioides immitis, Coccidioides posadassi (formerly known as non-California Coccidioides immitis) represents a divergent, genetically recombining monophyletic clade (Fisher et al. Mycologia 94:73-84, 2002). C. posadassii also differs phenotypically, this fungus has significantly slower growth rates on high-salt media when compared with C. immitis. Both fungi are dimorphic and cause the disease coccidioidomycosis, also known as valley fever.

bioproject.title: Strongylocentrotus purpuratus isolate:Spur 01 Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description: The Strongylocentrotus purpuratus genome has been sequenced using a combination of Sanger (~8X coverage), SOLiD (~18X), Illumina (~40x), and PacBio (~11X) by the Human Genome Sequencing Center<http://www.hgsc.bcm.tmc.edu/projects/seaurchin/> at Baylor College of Medicine, using a combination of whole genome shotgun (WGS) and BAC-based sequencing.

bioproject.title: Genetic linkage map from U.S. Meat Animal Research Center
bioproject.description: The U.S. Meat Animal Research Center (MARC) has constructed a genetic linkage map for Ovis aries.

bioproject.title: A radiation hybrid and several genetic maps have been generated at the Laboratory of Genomic Diversity
bioproject.description: The Laboratory of Genomic Diversity has been involved with the development for Felis catus of both a radiation hybrid map and several different genetic maps. An initial genetic linkage map was generated utilizing an interspecies backcross between the domestic cat and the Asian leopard cat (Prionailurus bengalensis). More recently, they have created a genetic linkage map from a large, multi-generational pedigree of domestic cats. Radiation hybrid maps for the 18 autosomes and chromosomes X and Y have also been developed.

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequenced by Pig Research Institute Taiwan
bioproject.description: The Pig Research Institute Taiwan, now named Animal Technology Institute Taiwan, sequenced the S. scrofa mitochondrial genome from a Landrace pig, and compared its organization to the mitochondrial genomes of Bos taurus (cow) and Balaenoptera physalus (fin whale). They reported their results in Lin et al. Gene 236(1):107-14, 1999. The sequence is available in GenBank (AF034253) and in RefSeq (NC_000845).

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequencing for Strongylocentrotus purpuratus
bioproject.description: The University of Glasgow sequenced the S. purpuratus mitochondrial genome, and compared its organization to the mitochondrial genomes of other echinoids and several vertebrates. They reported their results in Jacobs et al. J Mol Biol. 202(2):185-217, 1988.

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequencing for Ciona intestinalis
bioproject.description: The Universita di Milano sequenced the C. intestinalis mitochondrial genome, and compared its organization to the mitochondrial genome of C. savignyi and to the mitochondrial gene organization common to vertebrates . They reported their results in Gissi et al. J Mol Evol. 58(4):376-89, 2004.

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequencing for Ciona savignyi
bioproject.description: The Tokyo University of Pharmacy and Life Science sequenced the C. savignyi mitochondrial genome, and compared its organization to the mitochondrial genome of another urochordate, Halocynthia roretzi. They reported their results in Yokobori et al. J Mol Evol 57(5):574-87, 2003.
bioproject.organization: Tokyo University of Pharmacy and Life Science

bioproject.title: Medicago truncatula Transcriptome or Gene expression
bioproject.description:
M. truncatula EST sequencing project was started at the Center for Medicago Genomics Research which was created at the Samuel Roberts Noble Foundation with an aim to do large scale EST and genome sequencing, and functional analysis of M. truncatula genome. National Center for Genome Resources (NCGR) and the Virginia Bioinformatics Institute (VBI) helped with the bioinformatics part of the project. An EST sequence database, MGI, is available as a result of this collabrative effort. Functional Genomics part of the project was funded by an NSF grant

Genoscope has sequenced ESTs from three cDNA libraries derived from young root nodules.

bioproject.title: Weed legume with a small genome
bioproject.description:
Lotus japonicus is a wild legume that belongs to family Fabaceae. Members of this family are very diverse comprising of about 20,000 species. They are of significant agricultural and biological importance as many of the legume species are rich sources of protein and oil and can also fix atmospheric nitrogen.

L. japonicus has become a model plant for genome studies in legumes, particularly in reference to rhizobial and arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis. Small genome size of about 470 Mb, diploid genome with 6 haploid chromosomes and a short life cycle of about 2 to 3 months makes it a convenient plant to study. Kazusa DNA Research Institute in Japan, is presently the only institute involved in sequencing its genome. They initially sequenced the genome of Mesorhizobium loti, an endosymbiont associated with L. japonicus and then started sequencing the host genome. They also initiated the sequencing of ESTs and created high-density linkage maps of all six chromosomes. Data is available from the Kazusa web site.

L. japonicus does have several similar characteristics to the legume Medicago truncatula which is being sequenced by a consortium of laboratories in US and Europe, but they are phylogenetically different and exhibit two different development systems for nodulation.

bioproject.title: Rhyncholestes raphanurus, a South American shrew opossum, is one of only a few remaining in the Andes mountains
bioproject.description:
Rhyncholestes raphanurus is a South American marsupial and one of five remaining species of shrew opossum that exist in the Andes mountains. Shrew opossums are active hunters of insects, worms, and small vertebrates. They have poor eyesight, and largely forage in the evening and at night.

The mitochondrial genome of this animal has been sequenced.

bioproject.title: long-clawed shrew
bioproject.description:
Sorex unguiculatus is a marsupial, a long-clawed shrew, whose habitat includes the Pacific coast of Siberia and the islands of Sakhalin and Hokkaido.

The mitochondrial genome of this animal has been sequenced.

bioproject.title: genetic maps derived from L. japonicus Gifu B-129 and L. filicaulis
bioproject.description: Maps developed by Sandal et al used an F2 mapping population established from an interspecific cross between L. japonicus Gifu B-129 and L. filicaulis. 80% of the microsatellite markers generated for the cross between L. japonicus Gifu and Miyakojima can also be mapped in the L. filicaulis x L. japonicus Gifu mapping population, making it possible to align the two maps.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes important food-born disease
bioproject.description: Listeria monocytogenes strain 4b H7858. This serotype 4b strain was isolated from a hot dog during an outbreak of listeriosis that occurred in multiple states in the USA in 1998-1999.

bioproject.title: Opportunistic pathogen that causes important food-born disease
bioproject.description: Listeria monocytogenes strain 1/2a F6854. This serotype 1/2a strain was isolated from a turkey hot dog associated with a sporadic case of listeriosis in Oklahoma, USA, in 1988.

bioproject.title: The sea-firefly, Vargula hilgendorfii, is a bioluminescent crustacean
bioproject.description: The sea-firefly, Vargula hilgendorfii, is a bioluminescent crustacean. The luciferase from this marine ostracod has been used in expression studies in mammalian cells.

bioproject.title: little blue penguin RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly. Annotation provided on the RefSeq genomic records is based on NCBI annotation pipeline.

bioproject.title: the white-fronted goose
bioproject.description:
Anser albifrons, the white-fronted goose, has a large geographic range. During the winter, they migrate south into Europe, Asia, and North America.

The mitochondrial genome of this bird has been sequenced.

bioproject.title: The mitochondrial genome of the white-fronted goose has been sequenced
The Japanese spiny lobster, is an important commercial resource in Japan
bioproject.description: The Japanese spiny lobster, Panulirus japonicus, inhabits shallow coastal waters with rocky bottoms, and is distributed in the western North Pacific. In Japan, this species is an important commercial fisheries resource.

bioproject.title: mitochondrial genome of the Japanese spiny lobster
bioproject.description: Tthe mitchondrial genome of Panulirus japonicus. The 37 genes found in the mitchondrial genome is in the same order as most other arthopods.

bioproject.title: The mitochondrial genome of the cat has been sequenced
bioproject.description: The Felis catus mitochondrial genome was sequenced by the Laboratory of Genomic Diversity to study the evolution of different mammalian species.

bioproject.title: Complete mitochondrial genome sequenced by Justus-Liebig-University
bioproject.description: Justus-Liebig-University sequenced the Ovis aries mitochondrial genome and compared it to other the other major ovine haplotype group and to bovine species.

bioproject.title: Large barley EST data sets are being maintained by HarvEST:Barley database
bioproject.description:
Clemson University Genomics Institute is involved in Barley EST sequencing project with an aim of establishing a non-redundant barley EST resource. Different tissues from variuos cultivars have been used for generating ESTs. In addition, several other groups are also involved in Barley EST projects.

HarvEST:Barley database, developed at the University of California, contains large barley EST data sets from USDA-funded projects in the US, IPK in Germany, Okayama University and the National Institute of Genetics, Japan, Scottish Crops Research Institute, and University of Helsinki, as well as smaller datasets from several other contributors. This information is available as Barley1 Affymetrix microarray chip as part of the USDA-IFAFS project

bioproject.title: Triticum aestivum
bioproject.description:
Despite the economic importance of T. aestivum, genome sequencing has lagged behind in this crop plant because of the large and allohexaploid nature of its genome.

EST and full length cDNA sequences provide essential information about the transcriptome. As an alternative to whole genome sequencing, the wheat scientific community decided to generate large scale ESTs from wheat with a long term goal of assigning gene function and their location on the chromosome. International Triticeae EST Cooperative (ITEC), established in 1998, maintains an international public repository for ESTs from Triticeae species that include sequences from wheat, barley, rye, and other related species.
bioproject.organization: E. I. DuPont de Nemours and Company

bioproject.title: Zea mays Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description:
Zea mays (maize) has the highest world-wide production of all grain crops, yielding 875 million tonnes in 2012 (http://faostat.fao.org/). Although a food staple in many regions of the world, most is used for animal feed and ethanol fuel. Maize was domesticated from wild teosinte in Central America and its cultivation spread throughout the Americas by Pre-Columbian civilizations. In addition to its economic value, maize is an important model organism for studies in plant genetics, physiology, and development. It has a large genome of of about 2.4 gigabases with a haploid chromosome number of 10 (Schnable et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2009). Maize is distinguished from other grasses in that its genome arose from an ancient tetraploidy event unique to its lineage.
 The maize B73 reference genome has been revised three times since its initial release as a BAC-by-BAC assembly in 2009 (Schnable et al., 2009). This entirely new assembly of the maize genome (B73 RefGen_v4) is constructed from PacBio Single Molecule Real-Time (SMRT) sequencing at approximately 60-fold coverage and scaffolded with the aid of a high-resolution whole-genome restriction (optical) mapping. The pseudomolecules of maize B73 RefGen_v4 are assembled nearly end-to-end, representing a 52-fold improvement in average contig size relative to the previous reference (B73 RefGen_v3).

bioproject.title: Fast growing tree, first forest tree to be sequenced
bioproject.description: The genus Populus includes several fast growing trees like poplars, cottonwoods and aspens. It consists of more than 35 species distributed mainly in the Northern hemisphere. They have a small genome of about 550 Mb, about the size of the rice genome and four times larger than the Arabidopsis genome. They are considered paleopolyploids with all species having a haploid chromosome number of 19. Populus trichocarpa is a hardy, fast growing tree that can be propagated vegetatively. It has been chosen as a model plant for tree genomics because of its small genome size, rapid juvenile growth, ease of clonal propagation, high-throughput transformation and regeneration, and availability of extensive genetic maps. Populus genome will therefore be the first tree genome to be sequenced. Understanding this tree genome will greatly aid our understanding of growth and development processes in organisms that live for thousands of years.

bioproject.title: Pilot sequencing project on strain 1161
bioproject.description: The Sanger Center carried out a pilot sequencing project on the Candida albicans strain 1161 genome. Cosmids sequenced in this project have the accessions AL033391, AL033396, AL033497, AL033501, AL033502, and AL033503

bioproject.title: Genome sequencing of Populus trichocarpa, first tree genome to be sequenced
bioproject.description:
Joint Genome Institute of US Department of Energy is sequencing the genome of Populus trichocarpa clone 'Nisqually-1' by whole-genome shotgun method. The WGS project has been deposited in GenBank and has the project accession AARH00000000. It consists of sequences AARH01000001-AARH01041827.

The assembly was constructed with the JGI assembler, JAZZ, using paired end sequencing reads at a coverage of 7.5X. Sequencing and annotation has been a collabrative effort involving DOE Joint Genome Institute (JGI), DOE Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Genome Canada, Umea Plant Science Centre (Sweden), and Ghent University (Belgium). It is the first tree genome to be sequenced and the third higher plant sequenced by public funding.

JGI has also sequenced the poplar chloroplast genome. The complete genome sequence has the accession EF489041.

bioproject.title: Avirulent Burkholderia
bioproject.description: Burkholderia thailandensis strain E264. This organism was originally isolated from a rice field sample in Thailand. Strain E264 (ATCC 700388) is the type strain and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Populus trichocarpa annotation project
bioproject.description:
The annotation for version 1 of the P. trichocarpa genome was accomplished by Laboratories at JGI, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and the University of Ghent, Belgium.

The Swedish Populus Genome Project consisting of groups at Umea Plant Science Centre and the Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm has generated large collection of ESTs from various Populus species and more than 4000 full clone sequences that are being used for basal annotation of the Populus genome.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax and is gold standard for comparative genomics
bioproject.description: This is the type strain (0581, A2084, genotype 62, Group A3.b) for Bacillus anthracis and contains the two virulence plasmids, pOX1 and pOX2, that encode anthrax toxin and capsule, respectively, making this a virulent strain. This strain is considered the "gold standard" for B. anthracis.

bioproject.title: Sorghum bicolor Organism overview
bioproject.description:
S. bicolor is native to Africa and is grown throughout the world. Sorghum is the fifth most important cereal crop in the world and third in the United States. It exhibits C4 photosynthetic pathway. It is one of the most drought-tolerant crop that grows well in semiarid regions. It exhibits a deep root system and thick leaf wax. Both traits are thought to help it survive hot dry conditions. Some members of this genus are weeds but the domesticated varieties are used as human food and fodder. Certain varieties are sweet where grain and stem are used for making syrup, jaggery and sugar. Sorghum is also an interesting model to study drought tolerance as it is known to grow even if water becomes limiting showing a "stay-green" phenotype.

Sorghum has a small genome size of about 760 Mb with 2n=20 chromosomes, which falls between the genomes of rice (~420 Mb) and that of the other crops with a larger and more complex genome. The assembled chromosome pseudomolecules were submitted to NCBI in June 2009. The RefSeq records were created July 2009.

bioproject.title: Sorghum EST project
bioproject.description: There is an NSF funded project to generate ESTs from a variety of sorghum cDNA libraries obtained from S. bicolor and S. propinquum. The work is a collabrative effort between University of Georgia, Texas A & M University and USDA/ARS, and Drs. Sumio Sugano and Yutaka Suzuki of the Tokyo University College of Medicine.

bioproject.title: Bacillus cereus that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus cereus strain G9241. This strain of B. cereus was found associated with an anthrax-like disease in a patient. It was discovered that this organism harbored two plasmids, one that was highly similar to the Bacillus anthracis toxin plasmid, pOX1. The second plasmid contained genes that appear to encode polysaccharide capsule synthesis genes which are not similar to the Bacillus anthracis capsule synthesis genes on plasmid pOX2, but probably contribute to protection of the organism once it escapes into the bloodstream of a patient.

bioproject.title: Organism used restore gasoline-impacted aquifers
bioproject.description: Methylibium petroleiphilum PM1. Methylibium petroleiphilum strain PM1 (ATCC BAA-1232) was isolated in 1998 from the biofilter of a treatment plant in an oil refinery in Los Angeles, California. Strain PM1 is capable of degrading aromatic compounds such as benzene, toluene and xylenes. The MTBE and aromatic hydrocarbon degradation mechanisms used by strain PM1 are poorly understood, for which the genome sequence provides scientist with more information to improve the bioremediation properties of this isolate.

bioproject.title: Deep sea bacterium from hydrothermal vent near Hawaii
bioproject.description: Idiomarina loihiensis strain L20-TR. This is the type strain (ATCC BAA-735T; DSM 15497T) for this organism, which was isolated from a hydrothermal vent at a depth of 1300 m from the Lo'ihi Seamount southeast of Hawaii.

bioproject.title: Medicago truncatula strain:A17 Genome sequencing and assembly
bioproject.description:
A consortium of labs in US (University of Minnesota, University of Oklahoma, UC-Davis, and TIGR) and Europe (INRA-Toulouse with Genoscope, Waginingen University, and the John Innes Center with the Sanger Institute) are involved in an NSF and EU funded project to fully sequence the gene-space of M. truncatula. Its genome is organized into gene-rich euchromatin and repeat-rich pericentromeric heterochromatin.

A BAC-by-BAC strategy has been employed to sequence the genome. Oklahoma University is sequencing chromosomes 1, 4, 6, and 8 (initial sequencing funded by Noble Foundation). JCVI is sequencing chromosomes 2, and 7. JIC/Sanger is sequencing chromosome 3. INRA/Genoscope is sequencing chromosome 5.

International Medicago Genome Annotation Group (IMGAG) was established in 2004. Current members are from JCVI/TIGR, INRA-CNRS, MIPS, University of Minnesota, Ghent University, University of Oklahoma, and NCGR. The goal is to coordinate the generation of genome annotation for the model legume Medicago truncatula under the supervision of the sequencing project Steering Committee. Building on standards and processing protocols from the Arabidopsis thaliana, rice, and other genome projects, a set of standards for gene identification, gene naming, data format, data processing and data exchange have been developed.

bioproject.title: Cyanidioschyzon merolae sequenced by whole genome shotgun method
bioproject.description:
Genome of C. merolae was sequenced by whole genome shotgun method. BAC libraries and a large-scale full-length cDNA library were also constructed and used for scaffolding. The sequences were assembled using Phrap, rexamined using ARACHNE and edited using CONSED.
Gene prediction and annotation was carried out by mapping ESTs obtained from the cDNA library onto the best-matched region of the genome and getting the ORFs likely to encode a protein showing similarity to known proteins. It was done using BLASTP or RPSBLAST and HMMER programs. The gaps between the contigs were closed by primer walking PCR, shotgun sequencing and BAC clone sequencing.

bioproject.title: Assembly and annotation of human chromosome 7
bioproject.description: This project provides a curated assembly and annotated view of chromosome 7. The annotation project includes genes, pseudogenes, ultra-conserved regions, mouse orthologs, variation, and more. The annotated assembly has been deposited at GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ under the project accession AACC00000000 .

bioproject.title: The Redbanded seabream is a commercial fish that is also an aquarium fish
bioproject.description: Pagrus auriga, the redbanded seabream, is a commercial fish that is also used as an aquarium fish.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. A1055. This strain comes from the laboratory of Paul Keims.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. CNEVA-9066. This phylogenetically diverse strain is found in France.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. Vollum . This strain is used in research studies and is found in the UK, Spain, and Zimbabwe.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. Australia 94. This virulent strain, also known as strain A0039, is found in Australia and will be used for comparative analysis.

bioproject.title: Cyanidioschyzon merolae chloroplast genome
bioproject.description: The plastid genome of C. merolae is a circular molecule of 149,987 bp. It contains 243 genes distributed on both strands. It has short intergenic regions and lacks intron. This genome encodes several genes that are rarely found in other plastid genomes.

bioproject.title: The mitochondrial genome of the duck-billed platypus has been sequenced
bioproject.description: This group sequenced the mitochondrial genome of the platypus to help reconstruct the phylogeny of mammals.

bioproject.title: Ornithorhynchus anatinus, or duck-billed platypus, is a primitive egg-laying mammal
bioproject.description: Ornithorhynchus anatinus, or duck-billed platypus, is an important model organism for developmental, evolutionary, and genomic studies. The platypus and two species of echidna comprise the monotremes (prototherian mammals). Monotremes diverged from therian mammals (marsupials and placentals) approximately 210 million years ago and, not surprisingly, retain a mixture of reptilian and mammalian features. Monotremes are best known for their mixture of primitive and derived reproductive traits. For example, monotremes lay eggs but also have mammary glands. In platypus, eggs are nourished in the uterus for approximately 28 days and then externally incubated for 10 days. As in birds and other reptiles, the platypus karyotype consists of a few macrochromosomes and many microchromosomes. Platypus have 52 chromosomes. Males are heterogametic with 21 paired chromosomes and 10 unpaired chromosomes (X1-5 and Y1-5). During meiosis these unpaired chromosomes form a linked chain of elements. Though the sex determination system of monotremes is still incompletely understood it offers tantalizing clues to the ancestral sex determination system of birds and placental mammals.

bioproject.title: The red junglefowl or domestic chicken
bioproject.description: The chicken is a domesticated form of the red junglefowl (Gallus gallus) that is native to Asia. The chicken is an important agricultural animal and has served as a model organism in many areas of biomedical research; it is one of the primary models for embryology and development, the study of viruses, and cancer. The chicken genome is less than half the size of that of mouse or human, and consists of 38 autosomes and two sex chromosomes, referred to as Z and W. Unlike mammals, male birds are homozygous (ZZ) while females are heterozygous (ZW). Chicken chromosomes, like other avian species, exhibit a much greater variation in size ranging from 200 Mb to 5 Mb; the smaller chromosomes are termed "microchromosomes".

bioproject.title: The turkey, an agriculturally important avian species, has a karyotype that is similar to the chicken's
bioproject.description: The turkey (Meleagris gallopavo) is an agriculturally important avian specie with a genome very similar to that of the chicken. Expanding the marker and map information for turkey will also improve genetic information available for other agriculturally important avian species.

bioproject.title: The Japanese Quail is a migratory bird of South Asia
bioproject.description: The Japanese Quail Coturnix japonica is commonly used in developmental biology studies. Quail eggs and meat are a common food source in some Asian cultures.

bioproject.title: Sequence and gene organization of the chicken mitochondrial genome
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome of the White Leghorn chicken was sequenced by Desjardins and Morais at the Universite de Montreal for comparison to the mitochondrial genomes of other vertebrates.

bioproject.title: Reference genome sequence
bioproject.description: The Reference Sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is provided by NCBI using assembly instructions provided by the Genome Sequencing Center at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. The assembled genome is distributed internationally by FTP and the same assembly can be viewed in browsers provided by NCBI, Ensembl, and the University of Santa Cruz (UCSC).

bioproject.title: Consensus linkage map for East Lansing, Compton, and Wageningen chicken populations
bioproject.description: Three chicken populations (East Lansing, symbol E; Compton, symbol C; Wageningen, symbol W) have served as sources for genotyping data. The combined linkage framework map contained 480 loci that were ordered on 50 linkage groups. There are a total of 350 markers; of these 201 are either known genes or have significant sequence identity to known genes.

bioproject.title: Genetic linkage map of turkey based on microsatellite markers
Sequence of the mitochondrial genome of the Japanese quail for comparison to related species
One of approximately 47 species of tinamou, birds evolutionary related to ratites and Galliformes
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of extant ratites
One of approximately 47 species of tinamou, birds with close evolutionary relationships to ratites and Galliformes
bioproject.description: The great tinamou (Tinamus major) is a bird phylogenetically related to ratites, which are large flightless birds, and to Galliformes. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of both groups of birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of extant ratites
Kiwis are flightless, nocturnal, birds native to New Zealand
bioproject.description: The great spotted kiwi (Apteryx haastii) is a nocturnal ratite ( flightless bird). Kiwis are the national bird of New Zealand. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of ratites and Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: great spotted kiwi RefSeq Genome
bioproject.description: The reference sequence (RefSeq) genome assembly is derived from the submitted GenBank assembly. Annotation provided on the RefSeq genomic records is based on NCBI annotation pipeline.

bioproject.title: The Chinese painted quail is a galliform bird
bioproject.description: The Chinese painted quail, also known as Asian Blue Quail, King Quail or Blue-breasted Quail, is a bird that reproduces readily in captivity and has many color mutations. They are also used to study parthenogenesis - the embryonic development of unfertilized eggs.

bioproject.title: An extant ratite that has a threatened conservation status
bioproject.description: Darwin's rhea (Pterocnemia pennata) is a ratite or flightless bird. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of ratites and Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: The ruddy turnstone is a migratory shorebird
bioproject.description: The ruddy turnstone (Arenaria interpres) is a migratory shorebird found along shorelines. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of Gallinaceous birds with those of ratites or flightless birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: The ostrich is a ratite and the largest living bird
bioproject.description: The ostrich (Struthio camelus) is the largest living ratite or flightless bird. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of ratites and Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: The emu, a ratite, is the second largest living bird
bioproject.description: The emu (Dromaius novaehollandiae) is one of the largest living ratites or flightless birds. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of ratites and Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: One of the eleven moa species that became extinct after human colonization of New Zealand
bioproject.description: The little bush moa(Anomalopteryx didiformis) is an extinct ratite or flightless bird from New Zealand. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of extinct and extant ratites with those of Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: One of three extant cassowary species; ratite birds that inhabit rainforest
bioproject.description: The cassowary (Casuarius casuarius) is ratite, or flightless bird, from the Australian rainforests. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of extant and extinct ratites with those of Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: One of the eleven moa species that became extinct after human colonization of New Zealand
bioproject.description: The eastern moa (Emeus crassus) is an extinct ratite or flightless bird from New Zealand. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of extinct and extant ratites with those of Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: An extinct ratite bird from New Zealand
bioproject.description: The giant moa (Dinornis giganteus) is an extinct ratite or flightless bird from New Zealand. Comparison of the mitochondrial genomes of extinct and extant ratites with those of Gallinaceous birds has been used to delineate the relationship and distribution of ratites.

bioproject.title: The white stork is a large wading bird of Eurasia
The oriental stork is a large wading bird of Japan, China, Korea and Russia
The village indigobird is a brood parasite on another bird species.
bioproject.description: The village indigobird (Vidua chalybeata) is unusual in that the young are foster-reared by adults of a different specie of bird, red-bellied firefinches (Lagonosticta senegala). Comparison of the mitochondrial genome of this bird has been used to help delineate relationships among birds, and between birds and reptiles.

bioproject.title: The grey-headed broadbill is a passerine bird of equatorial Africa
The peregrine falcon is a widespread bird of prey
bioproject.description: The peregrine falcon, Falco peregrinus, is a raptor that preys primarily on birds. This falcon is found on nearly every continent and is one of the fastest animals on the planet. In a natural setting, they breed on cliffs but they also breed readily on building ledges in urban environments where pigeons are easy prey.

bioproject.title: The redhead is a North American diving duck that inhabits shallow freshwater bodies of water
The rook is a crow-like bird of Eurasia
The greater rhea is a large flightless bird of eastern South America
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extinct ratite
Sequence of the mitochondrial genome of the blue-breasted quail for comparison with that of related species
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant shorebird
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant ratite
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant shorebird
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome to determine phylogeny of raptors
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant ratite
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant ratite
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extinct ratite
Sequence of mitochondrial genome of an extinct ratite for comparison with extant ratites
Sequence of the mitochondrial genome of the white stork
Sequence of the mitochondrial genome of the Oriental white stork
Sequence of mitochondrial genome of birds for comparison to that of other birds and reptiles
Sequence of the mitochondrial genome of birds for comparison to that of other birds and reptiles
Sequence of mitochondrial genome of birds for comparison to that of other birds and reptiles
Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of a North American duck
BAC end sequence project
bioproject.description: End sequences from bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs) provide highly specific sequence markers in large-scale sequencing projects. BAC end sequences (BESs) support quality assessment, sequence assembly, and comparative genomics.

bioproject.title: Sequence and comparison of the mitochondrial genome of an extant ratite
The NIH Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC) program aims to identify, sequence, and provide full-length cDNA clone reagents.
bioproject.description: The NIH Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC) program is a multi-institutional effort to identify, sequence, and provide a community resource of cDNA clones containing a full-length open reading frame (FL-ORF) for human, mouse, and rat genes. All clones generated by the MGC are publicly accessible to the biomedical research community through the IMAGE Consortium distributors.

bioproject.title: Large-scale sequencing of full-length cDNAs and clone distribution.
bioproject.description:
The NEDO full-length human cDNA sequencing project involves a large-scale collection and sequencing of full-length cDNAs with the support of NEDO.

In 2001, about 160,000 clones were isolated from more than 20 full-length enriched human cDNA libraries made by the "Oligo-capping" method. Their 5'-end sequences were determined. Approximately 10,000 putatively full-length cDNAs were selected using these sequence data. The entire sequence of the selected clones was also determined. This project will continue for another 2 years with the aim to determine the sequence of an additional 20,000 full-length cDNA clones.

The NEDO project (FLJ sequences) is a joint program of three clone distributors: The University of Tokyo (Dr. S. Sugano); Helix Research Institute (Dr. T. Isogai); and Kazusa DNA Research Institute.

bioproject.title: Large-scale sequencing of full-length cDNAs and clone distribution.
bioproject.description: A consortium of eight DNA sequencing laboratories and one of Germany's leading bioinformatics institutes was founded in September 1997 within the German Human Genome Project (DHGP). The aim of this project is to characterize a large set of cDNA clones not yet identified in other projects; over 3200 have been sequenced to date. Clones from chromosome-specific libraries and tissue-specific libraries enriched in full-length clones generated at the DKFZ are characterized by partial sequence analysis (EST sequencing). Selection of clones for full-length sequencing is based on the EST data that are analyzed at MIPS. Reagents are available through RZPD.

bioproject.title: Large-scale sequencing of full-length cDNAs and clone distribution.
bioproject.description:
The Kazusa Institute has identified and sequenced over 2400 full-insert cDNAs with the aim of identifying long (>4 kb) cDNAs encoding proteins over 50 kD. Reagents are available upon written request.

The related database of human unidentified gene-encoded (HUGE) large proteins provides information about the clones.

bioproject.title: Soil organism that produces potent insecticidal toxin (human isolate)
bioproject.description:
Bacillus thuringiensis. This organism, also known as BT, is famous for the production of an insecticidal toxin. The bacterium was initially discovered as a pathogen of various insects and was first used as an insecticidal agent in the early part of this century. This organism, like many other Bacilli, is found in the soil, where it leads a saprophytic existence, but becomes an opportunistic pathogen of insects when ingested. The specific activity of the toxin towards insects and its lack of toxicity to animals has made this organism a useful biocontrol agent. The delta-endotoxin, which is produced during the sporulation part of the life cycle, causes midgut paralysis and disruption of feeding by the infected insect host. The presence of a parasporal crystal, which is outside the exosporium of the endospore, is indicative of production of the toxin, and serves as a marker for this species.

Activation of the toxin typically requires a high pH environment such as the alkaline environments in insect midguts followed by proteolysis. Binding of the toxin to a receptor on intestinal epithelial cells serves to position the toxin to insert itself into the apical membrane where it forms a pore. The flux of water and ions into the cytoplasm results in eventual lysis leading to tissue damage. Various toxin genes specific for a variety of insects have been studied, and many are now being used in genetically modified plants which have been engineered to produce the toxin themselves, eliminating the need to produce sufficient amounts of B. thuringiensis spores.

Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. konkukian serotype H34 strain 97-27. This organism was isolated from a case of severe human tissue necrosis which is unusual since human infections by this organism are rare. This isolate is very closely related to B. anthracis based on phylogenetic analysis.

bioproject.title: Endospore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax (avirulent derivative used for vaccine development)
bioproject.description: Bacillus anthracis str. Sterne. This strain carries the anthrax toxin plasmid pXO1 but not the capsule plasmid pXO2 and is therefore avirulent but toxigenic. It is the counterpart to the Pasteur strain that carries pXO2 but not pXO1. This strain is often used for vaccine development.

bioproject.title: Genome sequencing as part of the Citrus Genomics Project
bioproject.description: As part of the Citrus Genomics Initiative the genome of C. trifoliata will be sequenced. A 9X coverage BAC library is currently available for BAC fingerprinting, the first step in the development of contigs, and for BAC end sequencing.

bioproject.title: Human-specific organism that causes a variety of diseases
bioproject.description: Haemophilus influenzae strain 86-028NP. This nontypeable strain is a clinical isolate from a pediatric patient with otitis media from Columbus Children's Hospital. It has been extensively characterized in chinchilla models of otitis media.
bioproject.organization: Columbus Children's Research Institute and The Ohio State University, Pediatrics, USA

bioproject.title: A genome sequencing project from the Trypanosoma cruzi consortium
bioproject.description:
The Trypanosoma cruzi strain CL Brenner has been sequenced, assembled and annotated. The T. cruzi consortium consists of the Seattle Biomedical Research Institute (SBRI), Uppsala University, Karolinska Institute and The Insitute for Genomic Research (TIGR).

To sequence the genome of T. cruzi strain CL Brener, SBRI used a whole genome shotgun approach; TIGR and end-sequencing of bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clones and a chomosome by chromosome approach. Approximatelly 60.4 Mb out of a ~108 Mb T. cruzi diploid genome has been annotated.

Additionally, Uppsala University and Karolinska Institute generated close to 5000 Expressed Sequence Tags (ESTs) from a normalized T. cruzi epimastigote cDNA library. The ESTs corresponded to 3,054 transcripts and likely represent over 25% of the total gene content present in T. cruzi. About 30% of the transcripts have similarity to sequences in the public databases.

The whole genome shotgun sequence data of T. cruzi strain CL Brener has been submitted to GenBank by TIGR.

bioproject.title: A genome sequencing project from the Trypanosoma brucei consortium
bioproject.description:
The Trypanosoma brucei genome sequencing project is a consortium consisting of TIGR and The Sanger Institute.

The Sanger Institute sequenced chromosomes: I (1.85 Mb), IX (3.5 Mb), X (4.4 Mb)and XI (5.2 Mb) using the whole chromosome shotgun (WCS) strategy (8-10x coverage of each chromosome). Chromosomes II-VIII were sequenced at TIGR by generating a 20 Mb of discontinuous sequence (first step) followed by 5-6 Mb of continuous sequence (second step).

Chromosome I is fully sequenced, assembled, annotated and was published in the year 2003. The genomic sequences and analyses of the 11 megabase-sized chromosomes were published in the year 2005. The annotation of chromosomes II-XI is being completed. An overview of the sequence status is given by the Sanger Institute.

The T. brucei genome is 26 Mb in size and it contains 9068 predicted genes, approximately 1700 of which are T. brucei-specific.

A comparison of the genomes of T. brucei, T. cruzi and Leishmania major revealed differences in the metabolic pathways of these parasites, and several drug targets have been proposed.

The T. brucei genome sequence data and annotation are available at GenBank with accession numbers AL929603 and AE017150 for chromosomes I and II, respectively; consecutive accession numbers CP000066 to CP000071 for chromosomes III-VIII, and accession numbers CM000207, CM000208 and CH464492 for the whole-chromosome shotgun projects of chromosomes 9 to 11.

Note: This strain is synonymous with Trypanosoma brucei brucei 927/4 GUTat10.1.

bioproject.title: horse
bioproject.description:
Equus caballus, the domestic horse, has played a crucial role in the development of human civilization. It has economic importance throughout the world and is used for transportation, work and entertainment. It is a model organism for research on biomechanics and exercise physiology. The genome sequence will facilitate the identification of genes that are involved in mammalian evolution and help us to better understand the genetic basis of diseases common to both humans and horses, such as allergies and arthritis.

The Equus caballus genome is distributed over 31 autosomes and two sex chromosomes.

bioproject.title: The mitochondrial genome of the horse
bioproject.description: The mitochondrial genome has been published.

bioproject.title: This group is sequencing ESTs of the horse
bioproject.description: This group will produce and sequence ESTs to generate ~80,000 equine-specific ESTs by sequencing cDNAs obtained from a number of equine cDNA libraries.

bioproject.title: Radiation hybrid (RH) map by Texas A&M University
bioproject.description: A second generation radiation hybrid (RH) map of the Equus caballus genome was assembled at Texas A&M University using a 5000rad horse x hamster radiation hybrid panel. The map includes 4103 markers assigned to all 31 equine autosomes and the X chromosome. The same group has also worked on the horse Y chromosome.

bioproject.title: A genetic map of the horse
bioproject.description: The International Equine Gene Mapping Workshop has begun to construct a genetic map of Equus caballus.

bioproject.title: Gasterosteus aculeatus overview
bioproject.description: Sticklebacks are a species of freshwater fish that have undergone a dramatic evolutionary radiation since the last Ice Age. Ancestral marine sticklebacks populated the newly created lakes and subsequently adapted to different environments. A number of sub-species have recently evolved multiple changes in their anatomical and physiological traits. Stickleback species are therefore a good model with which to study adaptive evolution.

bioproject.title: mitochondrial genome of the three spined stickleback
